This museum gives a great overview of the culture and mythology through art, and is additionally informative of how people chose to live their lives here. Added bonus: the grounds are spectacular and the four houses that make up the museum are broken up into different historic periods.
Lovely art. Worth a visit among the many galleries in Bali. We went there earlier this year and enjoyed the array and variety of art.
Take the time to enjoy Balinese art. I enjoyed wandering around lovely gardens and then galleries. Didn't seem as extensive collection as Neka but very enjoyable way to spend a few hours.
A must see...... Is much to see , and get nice view about art in Bali , also from past .Take enought time for , and it s helpful , if you know a bit about bali s history too.

Best cheesecake in Ubud!!!. The secrets out, the Museum cafe has the best (and possibly only?) real cheesecake in Ubud. Forget that raw stuff ick and indulge in a sugary baked delight of your choice: Oreo, lemon, plain or blueberry- my favorite and so delicious! Bring your bug spray-I was bitten 3 times in a hour. Oh, the museum is nice too!

Excellent legong show. This is a review of the Sunday evening legong show featuring the Peliatan Masters gamelan orchestra.We came to Ubud specifically to see gamelan music. My wife played in a gamelan orchestra in the US for several years.This is a show for tourists, and we don't care. We heard a lot of sort of junky gamelan music coming from temples around Bali, and we wanted to see some pros. These guys were top notch. The orchestra was very tight, very talented, and it was a delight to watch how much fun they were having playing the music. The lead dancers (male and female) were incredible.The only issue were the other tourists at the show. Some were taking flash photography or talking, which was kind of annoying. But regardless, we had such a great time we could have cared less.We were worried about the quality of some of the other nightly shows in Ubud, so we did some research and arrived at a short list of shows to see that promised top quality music. This was my favorite.

Wonderful gardens and paddy fields to relax in. A haven of peace in the bustle of Ubud. Art galleries of limited scale and with some ipressive works but real pleasure is in the live artists working and in the grounds

Tranquility in Ubud. This is an amazing place to visit in the town of Ubud. You could walk through town and the markets and be asked to take a taxi, get a massage or buy something you probably don't need for hours or you could visit this beautiful museum. Our daughter (seven) took a dance class from an experienced and world-traveled teacher. My husband and I took the time to just soak in the peaceful beauty at ARMA. Around every corner is a picturesque scene. The cafe is also worth a visit with beautiful and delicious Balinese food.
very good.. very nice place, good enviorment,,,,, its a shame that they dont take care too good for the art pieces.
Worth A Look. Spent a pleasant couple of hours walking around the grounds. Lots of art, both modern and traditional. Admission price includes a free drink at the cafe.

Definitely Worth a Day. Beautiful, a quiet oasis from the town right int he middle of town. The grounds are lovely and well tended. The architecture is impressive, with the stairs open to all buildings. We stayed for lunch, which was good and politely and competently served. The traditional Balinese art is a masterful collection.

Great place, check it out. This place was great, we came with our conference group, about a 100 of us, and I had no idea where we were going. I was very impressed by the place, modern art, paintings, sculptures, music, etc. Afterwards we went down to the "restaurant" but it was a catered meal for our group. Food was excellent, then these little Balinese girls came out and performed a traditional dance.
Great place to contemplate beauty . Lovely collection of works. They offer many workshops and classes. The grounds are a pleasure to explore and I just wanted to sit in the beauty and write.
Beautiful place. We visited to attend the cooking school, which was excellent. Great chef and comprehensive lesson. The place and gardens are beautiful and visit to art museum informative.

Grand Architecture, Great Collection. I love the Arma because it runs the gamut of contemporary artists, to many pieces done in the mindboggling complexity of the traditional Balinese painters, and a comprehensive Walter Spies collection. I love wandering the gardens between the buildings that house the different galleries. Even the stone carvings that embellish the doorways and windows are works of art to be studied and admired.
Great collection. Definitely worth seeing if you're in ubud for a couple of days. The art is rather new than traditional.
A good place to visit in the heat of the day. An Interesting collection of Balinese paintings in beautiful surrounds. We had some delicious snacks at the ARMA Thai restaurant after looking around.

Diverse art. So many beautiful pieces of artwork, can be a little pricey if you don't know the drill so always worth doing some research and haggle a little. In the end you will get some very nice art for a reasonable price.

Ok visit with the kids. We found it really hard to get basic information like opening hours for this museum. We visited today with our 3 kids and there were no workshops or practices going on. We were encouraged to stroll around the resort but that felt weird as we did not know if we were intruding on peoples holidays. The prices in the shop seemed pretty over the top and overall our kids (aged 8,12 and 14) found it boring. They preferred Puri Lukisan when we came to Ubud on our last trip to Bali. They were allowed to try the gamelan instruments and i think that was the highlight for them. There were signs up stating no photos but the book they give as you enter had pictures of at least 4 visitors taking photos of the art work?? Kind of eccentric museum. Good toilets though.
Nice to walk into after lunch. Good if u r into Bali art and its history. Some other galleries have a better range of modern art. Very nice.

Tranquil, relaxing .. highly recommend. With so many resort options in Ubud, we decided to stay at ARMA for 3-nights after a recommendation from a friend of a friend. It took us next to no time to start to unwind after a 5-day stay in Seminyak.We had the fortunate opportunity to view a number of the room styles and ended up staying in a family villa with our own pool. Daily buffet breakfasts were included in our tariff and a chef was on hand to cook eggs, pancakes, etc exactly to our liking. We dined at the ARMA restaurants and cafe each day, despite the amazing choice of venues in Ubud Central which we drove past in the shuttle each day. A jazz night was also held in the resort on one of the nights which was also a highlight of our stay. It was absolutely divine sitting at any one of the tables overlooking the magnificent gardens and rice paddies.We enjoyed our cooking class with the very personable chef and she was on hand each day to mingle with the guests. The batik class was interesting but we struggled a little not understanding our artist teacher. The owner of the resort was present but discreet when pointing out the serene walks that guests could partake in and most nights featured traditional music or dance in one of the many stages dotted around the resort.The staff were extremely helpful and wanted to make sure we were happy - which we were!

Barong dance. I visited here to see the Barong dance at open air stage,not painting.Performance's ticket is available here,not tourist's information near Ubud palace.This premise is really huge include hotel,cafe,river,garden,museum,stage even rice field.It is worth to just walk around.
Interesting. Go there and have a look at the collection of paintings to get a bit of an idea about what Ubud was before we - the touris - arrived. A place in heaven.

It's not just a museum! Must visit for people all ages!. We read about ARMA on tripadvisor and decided to fit it in if we had some time in ubud..we ended up spending 2-2.5 hours there completely enthralled by the beauty that it is!It's known for its museum which houses collections of paintings/ art in about 3 buildings ..which show Batuan paintings and some modern art as well..very interesting stuff! But what's interesting is that there's more to it than the museum...it's a complete art and culture lesson on Ubud and Bali..there are painting classes and dance classes that are conducted in the serene surroundings within the ARMA resort..it was so enriching to see little girls learn dance to the soothing beats of Balinese music..the lagoons, small rivulet flowing through and aesthetically done villas in the midst of paddy fields are all a treat to watch.. it looks like a place designed and built with a lot of passion and interest..infact it would be a great idea to stay here in ARMA resort..you could actually learn some painting and dance..for the fee of IDR 30.000, you even get to have a complimentary coffee/tea at their ARMA cafe..again very nicely done..This place is like a mini Bali within Bali..we would highly recommend it for the beauty of the place and the kaleidoscope to Balinese culture that it is !!!!

A rich collection, and a magical place to visit. The Agung Rai Museum of Art is not just a museum but also a resort with restaurants, a rice field, and a cultural centre that educates children (look up the Agung Rai Foundation). The collection is well curated. There is a mystic and intriguing beauty about many of the traditional paintings displayed. Many of them will take your breath away! I had the privilege of meeting Mr. Agung Rai who happened to be watering the plants (such a humble genius).

Lovely cool gallery. This galley is part of a lovely natural complex south of Ubud town. The galley itself is spacious and feels cool, and houses some interesting traditional and contemporary Balinese art. Take a walk beyond the galleries into the artists village / hotel area - rice fields, lotus ponds, and individual villas. We may well try to stay there during our next visit to Ubud.
Quality modern Indonesian art. A spacious gallery that always has interesting things and an informed director. No rubbish here, the works are aimed at an international clientel.

Lovely way to spend a few hours. The museum is interesting, I'm glad I went, and if you're on a day trip from the South it will give you a great overview of Balinese history. But what I really loved was wandering around the gorgeous grounds - just beautiful. Not only did i have lunch there- but I took one look at the pool and booked a hotel stay. The villas are to die for.

Great, especially Sunday Morning. Love to watch the children learn Balinese dance around 10AM each Sunday. Remember this is Bali time not real time, but a memorable experiance. Lovely grounds and a nice museum are a bonus

Worth a whole day in Ubud. Unaccustomed to heat and humidity, I decided to move around minimally and make the most of every outing. My son and I actually spent the whole day at ARMA, strolling the gardens, having lunch, touring the museums (ancient Balinese and Modern), attending the outdoor gamalan concert, even having massages at the spa within the gardens. It was a perfect day, and we avoided spending time sitting in traffic.

Came here for an auction -- blown away. I came here for an art auction. The grounds were really spectacular and the owner's mission in creating this place is wonderful: to preserve Balinese culture and art, to make sure Balinese know about their culture and art and feel pride about it, and to help Balinese people continue in the making of the art. The cafe was delicious! I had the buff and everything on it was exceptionally good. Also loved the shop and bought a romper. Loved the place!

An introduction to Balinese Art. We loved the setting and the chance to see local art. We were introduced to Walter Spies, who was very influential in the 1920's - 1930's. The setting in tropical gardens is superb, as is the building itself, built to house these artworks.
Excellent art museum. This museum gave us a really good overview of Balinese art. It is set up on lovely and peaceful grounds where you can stroll a bit before or after your museum tour.

Amazing. I loved it here. I thought the works of art were incredible and the museum itself was beautiful. I felt like I was wandering around a palace. Be sure to wander around the resort as well, it's stunning. I was lucky to spend a few minutes talking with Ketut who showed me his unbelievable work carvings - and even let me try!You get a free coffee or tea with admission. It's open every day of the week!

Special quiet place .gardens and art. A great escape from the ubud crowds and activity . Some great art fantastic gardens . Coffee house included in ticket was very good . make sure you head down the hill to the river and bridges

One of the best things in Ubud. The ARMA museum and gallery had a wide range of paintings, from old to modern, and a range of lovely sculptures in an extensive and beautiful garden at the back , with lily ponds and bridges. Romantic and definitely worth a visit. It also had a nearby cafe tho we didn't eat there.

Lovely. This is a peaceful lovely place quiet opportunity to be close to nature. Museum of local art is very interesting. Best is a piece of textured rice fields at harvest in the modern gallery. Incredible .Thai restaurant in garden is good choice .
Nice. good insight into traditional balinese art and art history, go there and relax from (Kuta) Ubud mainstreet.
Cultural Experience. Mr. Agung Rai's love of Indonesia art especially Balinese art truly showcase in the museum. Very peaceful place to visit and enjoy.

Beautiful museum with interesting artwork . A visit to this museum is an absolute must for your stay in Ubud. Entrance is only IRp. 60,000 per person and includes a free tour book plus a tea or coffee in the serene cafe. As well as seminal works by the Indonesian artist I Dewa Nyoman Leper and the great practitioner of real magicalism Water Spies, the tranquil surroundings are a great way to get out of the sun and crowds and enjoy the peace of natural Ubud.
Go There. Not to be missed for a relaxing getaway in the middle of Ubud. A wonderful collection and a free drink in the cafe included in the ticket, very lovely and peaceful.

amazing. There are a lot of reviews on trip adviser about places in bali that are misleading but the agung rain is truly stunning. Advice! Go after lunch about 2pm then stay the after noon and watch a show in the evening... if your lucky you can meet the founder.. amazing and down to earth man
lovely gardens. A beautiful place to visit. Interesting modern and traditional art. Lovely coffee shop to end the visit.

Impressive art collection and lovely setting for evening dances. Very impressive collection of Balinese art and other genres. Some stunning statues and carvings in a Balinese style building. Definitely recommend seeing the local dances here in the evenings, the dance troupes are highly rated.

Beautiful Art and Gardens. The magnificent establishment reminds me of a TARDIS from the Dr Who franchise - it is bigger on the inside than expected. There are different buildings that house the collection, with the buildings themselves act like art work with ornate carvings framed by the lush garden surroundings. There is a lot to see, and sadly we had to rush due to time constraints. There are two areas to have refreshments and something to eat, plus toilet facilities so you can take your time gazing at the art work Bali has to offer.

Great Relaxing place . The paintings exhibited are nice and interesting. Good place to learn and appreciate traditional Balinese culture.But the museum grounds are expansive -The museums, a couple of cafes, all the trees and greenery , a villa resort , rice padi fields - all together makes this place amazing and super coolReally relaxing and tranquil!

Fun and authentic. My wife and I visited this museum on our most recent visit to Bali. It consists of two art galleries, a garden, and a resort. The art galleries and the garden are quite nice and we enjoyed them. The main show however, is the Balinese dance at 7 pm. This is an authentic dance performance! You are provided with a sheet explaining the performance. Definitely worth the experience. There is also a related cafe just outside the museum; be sure to check it out.

Great Food Great Staff. Excellent food, nice location close to the city center, a lot of varieties, nice service. You may find locals or international food here. So tasty, nice presentation friendly staff.
pleasant surprise. I was amazed by the setting, the Balinese art collection, the cafe/restaurant (belgian beers).The garden is beautiful and well maintained. Saw children rehearse balinese dances.
Average.. Seemed a bit average. Not worth going out of your way for. If it was walking distance it might have seemed ok.

Do not give this museum a miss!. The museum is really beautiful. The grounds, the collection, the café etc. I felt relaxed as I was walking around the area. I particularly love the modern arts collection. I was entranced by Ida Bagus Purwa's Fire Dancer.

Super place. Get your camera ready.. We found the place quite good. Taken plenty pics around the Museum. There are like 3-4 entrances to the Museum. So if you are going on your own there, make sure which way you came.They do have Balinese Dance on Fridays @ 730pm. (Timings may vary).Entrance IDR 60,000. Comes with a complimentary drink (Coffee or tea, Hot or iced).

Lovely setting; fantastic collection. The grounds are lovely and the art collection covers a wide array of Balinese works. It is easy to spend 2 hours in the museum and another hour walking the well-maintained grounds. Agung Rai sounds like quite the personality and he infuses his museum with his choices

Beautiful Setting. The museum is not far from the Sacred Monkey Forest and well worth the 60k Rp entrance fee. The gardens are lush and spectacular, with paths which lead to 2 large buildings where the artworks are housed. One of the buildings is a more eclectic mix of modern style Artists. Whilst the other houses older traditional paintings, many of which the year of origin is unknown.

amazing building, garden , cafe and best of all the ART. Stunning place with the most beautiful grounds and exquisite buildings housing incredible art: sculptures, Balinese painting and fantastic fine drawings and paintings by the Dutch who visited in the last century. It is worth a good hour or two to browse and also a superb meal/ coffee etc at the cafe. The Balinese coffee was my favourite. Great shop too: really high quality.

A must visit museum for all museum go-ers and Art lovers. If you love museum and art... you must not miss here during your trip.There is a huge collection of art works, mainly paintings... Majority of them are related to the culture and traditions of Bali, we were lucky that our private tour guide explained some of them to us. Else we are very much likely to be clueless... As we do not have much research done before hand... there are many amazing and beautiful paintings here... there is one in particular that I personally like alot is the huge oil painting of the paddy rice field... amazing!Not sure if there is any guide service or audio guide here. But it would be perfect if there is.....

A lovely, quiet museum in a beautiful setting. A good place to start in Ubud if you're thinking of buying any Balinese artwork. An historical overview of local art that will help you separate the junk from the jewels. Adjoining their coffee shop is a little gift shop well worth a look.
Must see. Beautiful setting - great selection of old and new Balinese art - and good free wifi in the tea house
beautiful place. the art is interesting, the gardens superb and if you time it the classes for local children in dance and music are great to watch.

Nice museum of culture and art. Large collection of paintings from all over the world gathered in two buildings inside the compound. Facility also offers hotel, restaurant and cafe with very nice people.
At night they run a dance show with interpretation of balinese history and culture.
Ok but now a resort. Nice museum, but it's been turned into a villa resort which is a bit strange. Grounds are gorgeous, but you're literally walking past people's bungalows.
Wonderful treat.. Very fine collection. Well cared for, easy to find and well worth the stop. The collection is varied and tastefully presented. The facility is clean and tasteful.

Unexpected tranquility. From the busy main road rushing through Ubud you step into an oasis of calm and tranquility hosting genuinely amazing art works. Two buildings host a range of modern and traditional Balinese paintings set in a green garden shared with the ARMA resort. If you are lucky you may meet Agung Rai who seems to love meeting visitors and sharing a few tips on his huge collection.Well worth a visit and you can easily spend a couple of hours including taking your complementary drink at one of the peaceful cafes onsite.

A don't miss experience. This is not a place to rush around "doing" the sight. Instead, it needs slow absorption at many levels to truly appreciate this as a total experience. So please leave ample time for this. Look, savour, enjoy, sit, relax, and then marvel at what you've seen before you repeat the entire process. The grounds of this enchanting estate set the pace: they are soothing and tranquil with trees and plants, many with exotic flowers. Set within are the museum buildings, one part given over to traditional Balinese art: a delight for us as Indians because the mythology is so familiar. Another building contains art that is more contemporary: look here for a dazzling painting of Bali's famous terraced paddy fields and for an old restored photograph of a noble couple from Java whish is reproduced in a painting.What is conducive to a long visit is that refreshments or a meal are available on the premises, so you don't have to rush off for food: we had a lunch at the restaurant and I would recommend that both for originality of menu as well as quality of food: prices not too bad either. One place I would happily return to.

A definite MUST. This is not just a museum, although it is also an excellent one with one building that has old paintings and the other one modern ones, it is also an experience of another quality. The buildings themselves are beautiful that house the paintings, the park surrounding the buildings are lovely and the fact that Agung Rai is himself present to talk to the visitors is a treat. This man had a dream at 20 years old to bring to Bali a museum to exhibit local painters and others who lived in Bali like Walter Spies. Given Rai's peasant background it was a long hard road to accomplish this mission. He and his wife have made it a world, not just a museum, within the grounds are rice fields that are cultivated, and Rai uses the museum as a cultural center for dance and music classes and performances. This place is gold. Enter into his dream.

beautiful grounds with art that depicts bali through the ages. This was something we decided to do last minute-as we hadn't visited any museums in Ubud-and was an interesting surprise.Acres of beautifully carved and landscaped grounds with art in every form.The were two gallery spaces,one that had traditional art which speaks so much about the Balinese culture and epics(Ramayana,Mahabarata) and one which had the work of modern artists.We spent sometime walking around their grounds and this is the place to be if you appreciate art and architecture.they even have shows of the kecak dance etc here-so incase you miss watching it elsehwere you can go here.The entry fee was around 65000 IDR-which is a little pricy and they were not so happy giving away the complimentary drink-but the rest of experience was totally worth it..

Golden Hour with Agung Rai. yes, I like Ubud. Why?Where else in the world there is such a cultural environment?The rice terraces, the pictoresque landscape and of course the people here ...In every travel guide you can read, Ubud is undisputed the spiritual and the cultural heart of Bali. You can hardly be overlooked, there are countless painters, sculptors, artisans and galleries ... and daily dance and gamelan performances.... And then there are in Ubud a couple of really interesting art museums ....One of these is the ARMA (Agung Rai Museum of Art) in Jalan Pengosekan.Although I always come back to Ubud for many years, I was so far not a single time in the ARMA, Big Shame on me !!!Anyway, these days I've finally found it now the way to the legendary ARMA. And what should I say? I'm totally excited now !Mr Agung Rai, the founder of the ARMA has taken several hours for me to show me the ARMA and to explain the concept of ARMA ,, which is much more than just a museum of art. And it is astonishing:: Agung Rai is not only an excellent connoisseur of art, successful gallery owner and entrepreneur, he is also a historian, archeologist, botanist, garden designer, culinary expert, and of course a great host ....and he is, as I now have seen, a true guru of sunlight !!!To uderstand what I mean, you have to come to ARMA and ask Agung Rai himself, whether you can accompany him on his spectatcular , early "Golden Hour" ....

It is more then Museum. It is definitely more then museum. It is culture centre, hotel resort, gallery and more in one. You can easy spend 3-4 hours there to see a lot of piece of art. You can see there modern art but traditional as well. Surounding are is very buetiful, quite and as ticket you will recieve coupone for complimentary drink in nice restaurant. Also you can visit several workshops there. Plan at least half of day for this visit.

Go!. This is such a lovely place to visit whilst in Ubud. You could spend an hour or two walking around the art gallery and the garden. I'm not sure why it's called a museum though. We kept bumping into "Agung Rai" who works there / owns the place. He was a lovely man, however he kept saying "it's so calm here and no one will hassle you or try to sell you anything". However after a while he tried to sell us his "Golden Hour" tour which was ironic. I would 100% recommend going here but I was just a little confused by him!

Amazing Museum. We ran into the owner - who told us a little bit about how challenging it was to assemble his amazing art collection. There was none left in Bali when he arrived - and he had to go to Europe to find and retrieve these works. And personally - I'm seriously glad he did!The museum stretches over several acres of gloriously landscaped grounds, and includes a hotel, a waterway, at least 2 restaurants, plus of course the Art Museum. There are English signs everywhere - so discovering the art was very easy. I loved that they included a free drink with your ticket - that provided us with a much needed break in the middle of our art explorations. Go - highly recommended.

A complex with various functions. ARMA is not simply a museum,housed with a rich collection of paintings in two buildings ------the Bale Daja and the Bale Dauh.From traditional to contemporary, I really enjoyed works by Balinese artists as well as Walter Spies. Besides the museum, the complex included a resort with villas surrounded by rice fields, open stage, Thai restaurant, coffee shop etc., If you are an art lover, try to spare your time here first in order to have a general idea of Balinese painting before you head for a gallery. Don't forget to have a free drink in Warung Kopi.

Love the collections!. Love the collections of the paintings. Since many of the paintings are related to Bali culture, I was lucky to have a balinese to explain them to me. So that I could enjoy more.

Limited in art by comparison. We went here expecting there to be a large collection of art. There is very little introduction at the gate, and you get a booklet about ARMA. It turns out that most of the large complex is NOT the museum - the museum consists of 3 buildings of art. There were 4-5 meaningful pieces of art from the 100+ year old artist I Gusti Nyoman Lempad, but from an overall Bali/Ubud art perspective this museum was rather lacking. The rest (majority) of the complex consisted of the villa, café, and the AR gallery (art for sale). If you have plenty of time in Ubud, you could spend some time here. If you are hiring a driver to take you around or have only limited time, I would recommend skipping this and checking out the active artists' work in the shops outside of Ubud.
Great local art. Great place to stop go whilst in Ubud and experience local Balinese art, would recommend it as part of a day trip to the Ubud area
Beautiful and relaxing. Many beautiful paintings in large houses.In a nice quiet park. U can stay 2 or 3 hours ...No noise.

great little art museum spanning Balinese art from pre-colonial times to the present day. always good to get an idea of art and culture when traveling- the museum gives a good overview of the artists of Bali and their influences both inside and outside their culture.

A rare historical portrait of Bali culture.. You need a good 2hours to immerse yourself in the gardens, take in the incredible art collection and stroll past the streams and rice paddy fields. The highlight for me was meeting the legendary visionary himself, Agung Rai who pretended he was the gardener :) when I asked him if he was the owner. I could see the passion in his eyes as he spoke of the way the light landed on the leaves of the trees. Free for Balinese so bring your driver in with you. Agung kindly said I could invite my motorbike taxi driver in for a look. Great concept. Support the arts and support the preservation of Balinese culture. The art is incredible with all kinds of mediums depicting the Baliness religion, way of life and it tells a story that you would never get in Kuta or Seminyak. Local children can do free arts classes here in dance, art and crafts. Its very important this museum is preserved and continues to cultivate the important respect for the Balinese way of life. Thank you Agung for meeting and stopping to chat to me. The free coffee at the coffee café is simply devine!

local art and auction. Art work highlighted the local culture. Beautiful facility and garden grounds. Be sure to visit during the art and dance demonstrations. Options to take class on local are available too.

Great Traditional Art and Historical Art Collections. Agung Rai offers one of the finest Collections of Gusti Lempads revered and talented art works in all of Bali among other interesting collections. Give yourself a good half day to wander through and soak up the art works on display . The Museum uses traditional Balinese architecture and the grounds are well landscaped and peaceful, there is a cafe restaurant on site and even bungalows to stay in .
Good. Covering a huge area and the gallery not to my expectations. The grounds are massive though and lots to look at.

Spent a nice afternoon. Like what the others have commented. This is quite a special place becos it has gallery, cafe and garden all in 1 place. It feels like walking into someone's backyard and discover the little treasures. The gallery is naturally ventilated. It is clean but not well maintainedI saw they have rice fields further behind the villa area but i didnt continue beyond it. We took a rest at cafe since the entrance ticket came with a drink.Overall i would recommend to art lovers. For non art lovers it can be a little boring and nothing special

Fantastic!. I'm not really an art lover, and didn't enjoy the art much. But the surroundings, landscaping, etc. is magical! Very green, relaxed environment, and courteous staff. The coffee shop and Thai restaurant was too good!

A very special museum. I first met Agung Rai in the 1980s. I was working at the National Gallery in Canberra - whenever I'd visit Ubud we would get together with local artist friends and have long fascinating conversations about Balinese art and culture.I especially loved to listen to his dreams for a world standard museum in Ubud, somewhere both a permanent collection and traveling exhibitions could be displayed. He'd describe it's future landscaping to me, and we'd discuss how it might also support a foundation for the arts. There would be workshops and performances and perhaps a restaurant set deep within it's intricate gardens.A few years after those conversations I was living close to ARMA and watched it's construction. It was quite extraordinary to watch this dream come alive. And now ARMA has been open for many years. It's galleries and gardens are stunning and it's a glorious place to spend several peaceful hours, away from the mad bustle of central Ubud. Your entrance fee includes a booklet with lots of info plus a free coffee at ARMA's very pretty restaurant. Come for the art, then stay for a meal or a performance. And say hello to Agung Rai who wanders the gardens most days and is always happy to talk about this very special museum that he has created.

A great place to visit with toddler. I'll be honest, I didn't see a huge amount of art and I can't say I learnt a huge amount on my visit here, but I would recommend it if you are travelling with young children who can walk. I visited with my two year old and we had a great morning here walking around the stunning gardens, watching fish, listening to music, watching wood carving and watching children take a traditional dance lesson. I had to ditch the stroller because there were steps up and down everywhere, but one of the restaurants was happy to look after it while we walked around. It was very peaceful and enjoyable to visit and I would say if you have kids with you, it's a good inclusion on your trip as they can run around in a confined place while you take in as much or as little of the culture as you need!

Perfect for a quiet afternoon. We made our way here from kuta, which took about 1 hour or so of driving. The art is definitely worth the trip, as a window into the Balinese culture (which you obviously don't get in kuta). One negative point was that the galleries were neither air-conditioned or even had fans, so that's something which made our rounds here a little uncomfortable and sticky. Though they have a nice little cafe you can sit in a gazebo by the rice fields and cool down with a free cup of iced tea or coffee.

One of Bali's best art museums, gardens, complexes.. More than a museum. Agung Rai's complex has a stunning garden and landscape which he's built the museum into it. Both the contemporary and Balinese collections are great; well-exhibited in beautiful, traditionally-styled Balinese buildings. Agung Rai suggested a walk around the surrounding area -- cafes, a resort, restaurant -- probably the most exquisitely designed garden area I've seen thus far in Bali. Go for the art museum but spend at least an hour wandering around the complex.

A good place to visit. Pretty much as previous reviewers have said, well worth a visit and allow yourself a good few hours. More art gallery than museum I would suggest, but some fascinating exhibits. If you're walking from downtown along jalang Pengosakan, look out for. the arma cafe on your left. You can short cut through there, I think. It certainly worked for me on the way out.

Not just a museum!. ARMA is a fabulous combination of galleries, beautiful garden, rice field and resort. Everything is green, beautiful and well taken care of. The ticket includes a complimentary drink at the bar. I highly recommend to pay a visit!

Not just a Museum...... The museum itself is fantastic..The art is incredible.However....its the restuarant itself that has been one of the Highlights of my stay in Ubud.A frequent visitor due to how close it is next to my hotel..I have built up a relationship with the staff there that I hadn't imagined possible. For instance, yesterday I sat with them and they taught me and allowed me to make the daily offerings there prepare with banana leaves...hours went by having great fun with them. They've taught me indonesian, balinese, kindly provided me with they're own staff dinner ...The people in Bali in general make it the beautiful place it is and it's all encapsulated in this one restaurant. The food I've not even mentioned...outstanding!Sumanga (hope spelt right), Suliani and Chandra are amazing people...even inviting me to they're local village for the upcoming New Year celebrations!Simply....Go!

Not to be missed.. This is a wonderful place, full of art and artifacts from Bali. The museum itself is a lovely building and the grounds are cool and relaxing. A cup of tea or coffee in the shaded outdoor cafe is included, as well asa super illustrated guide book. There is also a hotel and rice paddies on the site, and you can take classes in balinese art and dance. N
Nature and Culture. The museum building itself is not that big but its location and setting makes it very interesting. A portion of the land is still devoted to rice planting.

A beautiful oasis in the middle of Ubud. Do not miss a visit to this wonderful place set in lovely peaceful gardens .The 2 galleries have magnificent collections of paintings and there are regular cultural performances of dance and theatre as well as demonstrations of painting , carving , offering making and weaving. A must see for every visitor to Bali.We were priveleged to take part in one of Mr.Agung Rai's "Golden Hour" tours which was an unforgettable experience.Proceeds from visits help the Arma Foundation continue it's work in showcasing and preserving the culture of Bali.

Definitely worth seeing.. From the website where you are teased with images of what is to come to the actuality, the ARMA doesn't disappoint. Its value for money and given you can stroll around the grounds of the adjoining resort and admire the landscaping and buildings at your leisure, it is great value. I didn't find the modern art section to my taste but there is still plenty to see. And as for the smiling carved stone face that is the well recognized symbol of ARMA? It's one of the very small carvings that make up some of the retaining walls on the resort. Ask one of the older staff members for its location.

Not just a standard Museum! Definitely worth the Visit. I was pleasantly surprised to find that ARMA was so much more than a standard museum. There are rice fields you can walk through, beautiful scenery with different plants and trees from around the world, a beautiful river, restaurants and so much more! I was able to meet Agung Rai himself in the gardens and he was so kind and attentive, showed me different plans that Balinese people use for healing etc. we sat and had a nice chat about Bali, one of my favorite things I have done on my trip. I would highly recommend the visit!

My fave museum in Bali. A nice, little museum with a magnificent collection of pieces from both Balinese and foreign painters in a variety of styles. The artefacts were well organized, neatly displayed, and bore thorough captions. Located in a very prominent location and easy to discover, this is one museum in Ubud one a must go to.

Art, culture, food- a multi faceted xperience. As unusual a museum made up of Balinese style buildings as I have ever visited but enjoyed immensely.Lovely paths to walk on, collection of tress and, shrubs and plamts from around the world .Also a cenetr of performing and visual arts. Well worth the visit

wonderful afternoon at the Amar museum & resort. we thought we would visit a museum but in fact the experience was much wider than that. The museum is composed of 3 galeries from different chronologies, and really nice paintings. But we happen to meet Arung Rai in person in the gardens and we made together the visit of the wonderful gardens and ponds and rice fields and other facilities of the place. Everything is so nice and delicate : nature is really composing with art in this place. The ticket includes a complimentary drink at the bar. I highly recommend to pay a visit!

Best museum in Ubud. Gorgeous spaces both indoor and out, though nearly vacant when I was there. Stunning collection of pieces from both Balinese and foreign painters in a variety of styles. Everything was well displayed, easy to move between, and mostly had thorough captions. The few staff members left viewers to explore the exhibitions and surrounding landscape at their own space, but were very friendly and helpful when approached. The one museum in Ubud that was a must-go for me.
the best of Balinese Painting. Small, very well curated collection of traditional and modern work. The grounds are amazing. If you go to one museum in Ubud, make it this one.

The Art, The Arma, The Bali.. I have been a long time visitor to Ubud Bali (since 1991) and have seen Ubud and indeed the surrounds grow and when in Ubud I visit many favourite art museums. Top of the list is Agung Rai Museum (and Arma resort generally). To see the collection grow over the years has been a sheer delight, not only seeing the large traditional Balinese collection but to see the outstanding collection of contemporary art work which Agung Rai and his wife collect - and continually add to the museums collection. The resort is everything exquisitely Balinese with its palpable slow down pace - the cafes are relaxing no fuss no speed - and there's plenty of cool places to sit around the resort and contemplate; and the staff are always a delight and if you 'ease' down and talk slowly with the staff you'll find their English very clear. I will be in Arma in 2015.

Fantastic. I loved it so much I didn't want to leave ! The museum itself is interesting. The garden surrounding it is beautiful and so relaxing! I'm so glad the ticket included a refreshing drink otherwise may have skipped the beautiful coffee shop. There is a resort attached to the museum that looks amazing! So green and so relaxing it is hard to describe with words. If you are in bali, you should visit!

Intriguing Art Museum. I was not;t sure how much I would enjoy ARMA, but it is an intriguing and beautiful museum of modern Indonesian art, but my husband and i both thought it worth the visit.The museum and grounds are beautifully designed and landscaped and you can easily relax. The Balinese art illustrates the spirit of the island. There's no one there who speaks English, so you are on your own a bit. The foundation also runs a restaurant called ARMA to raise funds.The foundation has previously expanded to buy fields in the surrounding village to protect the farmers and the museum.
Gorgeous. Gorgeous grounds and beautiful art. A must go to. It's walking distance from most places in UBUD. Allow sufficient time to enjoy,

Should Visit Once. This Museum Of Art has a lot of paintings and some by very famous painters. The Balinese Painting section was amazing. Though one thing we didnt like was even though we bought the tickets which were pricey we weren't told that the muse would close in an hour. Hence we weren't able to complete the entire thing because they had started shutting the whole thing. So please check the closing time before buying the tickets.

Go to see the grounds. The grounds and buildings are lovely to explore. Sit down and enjoy old Bali. The paintings seem of a similar type. I probably would have enjoyed the paintings more with some explanation of the art works.

Nice. It was a nice museum but there is not much to see. I really enjoyed the hotel grounds as they were beautiful. You wouldn't spen a day here. The included coffee at the end was a nice touch and very welcomed.

All in One, Culture, Good Food , Art. Park your car, stay awhile. So much to see in this location. Have a coffee and dessert in the coffee shop after you have walked through the museum ,then sit down to delightful Balinese dishes.
Awesome Balinese Museum. Museum is a must for anyone visiting Bali. Located on the Grounds of the Arma Resort, this museum is filled with true Balinese Art.

Dive into ubud art history. Beautiful building and gardens. Artwork gave a good insight into Balinese cultural history . The restaurant option is worth taking as it is good value . You need about 90 minutes for a visit.
A nice afternoon out. Good art to enjoy in a lovely setting. Lots of lovely plants and flowers in the grounds. You get a drink as part of your ticket.

Not easy to find the location. We went there because of so many good online reviews. It is located inside a resort. But our local guide has no knowledge of this museum and we spent many effort to find the place. The are some very interesting paintings in the museum. By visiting this place, you can get some inside understanding about Balinese culture and the story of " Monkey King".

Tranquil setting. Wee visit museums and galleries everywhere we visit and this one was a real surprise ... Beautiful setting, gardens and pavilions with wonderful collections from Bali and Indonisian artists - inc contemporary work. You can take classes there at a reasonable price. Your ticket includes a free coffee in a lovely cafe house. To help pay for the upkeep the foundation have built luxury villas to rent by the museum ( probably beyond our budget but tastefully done). This was one of our favourite galleries ... A real gem.

To understand Balinese Art, Start Here. This beautiful museum is set in beautiful gardens. The art is hung chronologically and is very interesting. Most of the stories are from the Ramayama or the Mabharata and you see the same ones again and again. This makes the different styles of artists and times easy to track. I loved the spotted tiger.... The wood carvings are magnificent as well. If you can attend the lecture on Balinese Art given by Mr Agung Rai, thats very informative too.

Gorgeous eco-museum. Arriving in Bali from the UK we had many questions about all the different things we saw in Ubud. We went to ARMA expecting to see some art, but found ourselves leaving with a deeper understanding of everything we had seen so far through the museum's art collection and the interpretation provided.The museum is very reasonably priced and we spent about 3 hours there. Mr Rai is an excellent ambassador for Balinese culture, and wanders around the museum grounds chatting to visitors and making sure they have seen everything. In addition to the range of modern and traditional art, we saw children practicing traditional dance, wood carving (and had a go at carving ourselves), a free cooling drink in the cafe, walked around the beautiful grounds and rice paddies. The staff were all extremely helpful and friendly, and I urge you to make this your first port of call in Ubud!

Nice Museum Nice Resort. This place is a gem. The museum is great and well located. Amazing art inside. If you have the time walk down to the village and villas below the museum. The pictures you can take there are amazing. Go walk into the rice field, explore the expensive villas and sit and watch the river below. This is a very romantic place so if you have an important date, i will take her there for sure winner. After your walk you can come back up and sit and enjoy a free the or coffee offer with your ticket. Enjoy the visit, i sure did enjoy my visit.

Barong dance museum and show. Fantastic grounds, gallery and buildings followed by an open air dance performance of excellent quality . Live Gamelan music in a most beautiful setting. Highly recommend this as a performance venue without the crowds. Bring your mossie repellant although they do put coils etc around. Wonderful

Beautiful museum that preserves Balinese art!. The art was obviously beautiful and I learned a lot about traditional Balinese paintings! But what I loved the most, was the grounds- I really enjoyed the walking through, seeing Balinese sculptures surrounded by nature- the coy pounds etc.. Very nice cafe as well!

Lots of true Balinese art. This museum holds a lot of truly Balinese paintings. There are two galleries, one for historical works and the other for modern works. The work is mind boggling in its detail. I would have liked more descriptions with some of the work so I could get a better understanding of why these works are so important. The modern gallery gave food for thought but I found it more understandable. Well worth a visit. While you're there, take a break at the cafe. Its good too.

Eye opener. Magnificent gardens surround a number of small galleries. Provided a very interesting overview of the Balinese history and some wonderful pieces of art work. Yummy lemon tea from the cafe.
very nice gardens,nice resort. worth at least 1.5 hours,2 restaurants,decent art museums,scenic gardens,well worth the visit,also a coffee shop and store.some interesting paintings

Gorgeous throughout. Stunning grounds, fabulous art. My driver was chatting with a man who asked me if I liked it there. I expounded on the beauty of the place. He told me I'd convinced him to visit. Later, my driver told me he was actually the owner!

Very nice museum and beautiful grounds. The ARMA is a very nice museum with beautiful grounds. The museum buildings and the displays were very interesting and varied, with beautiful pieces, both traditional and modern. The grounds were also very nice, with the rice paddies and the luxurious pool and hotel grounds, all tucked away in an otherwise busy and noisy area.To top it off, Mr Rai himself was walking around the grounds, welcoming guests and pointing out interesting trees and plants. He has created a very beautiful space.
So So. Great batik at the end but the museum is nothing special unfortunately. They do have great dance programming at night.

Undiscovered delight in Bali. We went to Agung Rai Museum of Art yesterday for the morning, and although our driver hadn't been here before, I'm pretty sure he'll go back. The gardens are spectacular, the buildings interesting and fairly imposing, in fact they are artworks in themselves. A lot of the exhibited art wasn't to our taste, but that goes for any gallery. We felt that all round the various halls could have been better maintained, and decorated. Whilst the art is the main thing on display, a few softening touches in the decor would be nice. The coffee shop served a limited menu, but all nice. The staff were okay. We started talking to a lovely man in the grounds who told us a little about the gallery and accompanying Foundation. When asked how he was involved, he said he was in charge of the gardens....turns out he is the founder! We found this out much later. A gentle experience which we're glad we didn't miss. We heard the Thai Restaurant is excellent, as is the accommodation on site.

Abundant of collections. This place is massive, and it has the collection back from Majapahit era till present day.it's quite majestic setup as well, i didn't even manage to cover the whole paintings.

Great local artist display. Although the state of the building and the conservation of the paintings are terrible, the local artists pavilion is really inspiring. Fascinating paintings.The foreigners pavilion is awful, packed with mediocre artwork.

Most Attractive Place in Ubud. Ticket is 60k rp/person, but quite deserves it. We come across the low-key founder. He told us the fabulous building and garden was built in 16th century. He sponsor the Ubud children to learn arts in his museum for free. That's a really unselfish man with full of love.
Good introduction to Balinese art. Lovely place - several buildings in big grounds. A varied collection of Balinese art in traditional and modern styles. Well worth a visit.

Amazing arts and surroundings . Simply an amazing collection in a beautiful compound. Agung Rai is a man who is truly passionate about his collection. We were surprised to see him just walking around the museum and explaining the paintings to visitors. Ticket comes with complementary coffee/tea at a beautiful coffee shop overlooking rice field.
Very nice gallery. This place has a nice spacious layout with pretty gardens in the middle. The Balinese art is interesting but does get a bit samey after a while.
A visit is a must. Lovely museum and grounds with sections for mdern and traditional Balinese art. In the same complex there is gamalan music and dancing most evenings.

A one time visit. Nice museum with a bunch of paintings and statues. It was very hot and there were no fans here so we saw everything in a hurry. They should add some fans if they want us to spend more time here.

must visit museum in Ubud. Every little thing about this museum is just pretty.
The garden, the artwork, the building and surrounding are all pretty!
Im not so artistic person, yet the info panel in each artwork made it easy to understand what the info behind each installment. good for art beginner :)
The restaurant is cozy too

A remarkable oasis. The Arung Rai Museum is a great way to learn more about and enjoy Balinese arts and culture. The grounds are a real oasis amid the hustle of Ubud. Acres of beautiful plants, fountains, sculptures and paintings. Be sure to allow time to wander at will. The property is large, and there are so many different settings to enjoy. The artwork is intense, the level of craftsmanship is awe-inspiring, sometimes almost overwhelming, so we took breaks. We had tea seated against cushions in a pavilion overlooking the ricefield, wandered some more, and then had a late lunch at the Thai restaurant. It was all fabulous. We’ll go back on Sunday evening for the Barong and Keris dance performance.
Must see Balineese Art. Bali art collected from around the world. Life work of Agung Rai to repurchase the art from bali from around the world. The restraunt is very good too.

Great experience, great museum. There are three important art museums in Ubud and it's hard to say which is the best, but a visit to Agung Rai Museum of Art (ARMA) is certainly a very enjoyable experience. Even if you're not all that interested in art, you'll enjoy the atmosphere of this complex of museum, cafe, performance area and boutique resort. Set in spacious grounds, planted with tropical trees, orchids, gingers and other shrubs, many of which are conveniently labelled, the museum itself offers a timeline of the development of Balinese art, from the early Wayang style of monochrome painting based on Hindu legend, to the 20th century and the influence of foreign artists who settled in the area, to contemporary Balinese painters and sculptors. Take time to enjoy it, then visit the cafe for the free tea of coffee that comes with your entrance ticket.
Impressive. Here is where the traditional style of Balinese art is housed. There is an amazing collection, both indoors and out. The grounds are well maintained. Well worth the visit.
Nice!. It was worth visit once. Nice grounds to stroll around. Good collection of art pieces. Nice afternoon activity.

Just amazing!. We could have spent hours here just soaking up the peaceful atmosphere. Such a lovely place with an array of art of different styles and eras. All the art had great descriptions and we even got more information off of one of the guys who worked there. The free iced tea was definitely a bonus, and wondering around the gardens and rice paddies was so lovely. Definitely visit this place if you're in Ubud!

A Visual Feast, My Favorite Art Museum In Bali. From the moment that I stepped into the beautiful tropical gardens of the ARMA, I knew I was in for a visual treat. The soothing sounds of the fountains relaxed my spirit & opened my mind to the beauty that surrounded me. Stone sculpture frosted in soft green moss & decorated with flower offerings, pools graced with bright pink lotus flowers, elegant orchids in a variety of colors, all set the stage for the breathtaking art within the museum. Bali has to be an artist's dream place to express art. The color & the beauty can be see everywhere. In the natural flora & fauna, the rice fields, the deep river ravines, the jungle, the architecture, & the beauty of its people. All this & more is beautifully displayed on the walls of the ARMA. Take the time to treat yourself to the visual feast. You will find that it will refresh your soul.
just wow. actually im really blank about art, but after visit arma wooow, just look the painting make me feel soooo good, my fave painting is haven and hell..

Large complex, lots of sculptures. The grounds are large and filled with high quality sculptures. Take your camera and go in the morning for good lighting. I spent over 3 hours photographing the art and waterways. The staff are pleasant and spoke good English. I'd recommend this place to anyone visiting Ubud.

Absolutely worth visiting. ARMA is definitely worth visiting. The Artwork in the main Museum building is incredible. For those who aren't interested in art, the grounds of ARMA are full of beautiful gardens and stonework carving structures. In the afternoons they also have children learning to play the Balinese instruments and classes that cover other cultural aspects of traditional Balinese life/culture. The entrance fee is $6 AUD and this includes a complimentary drink at the Museum Café and also a booklet about ARMA. This place is privately owned and they do a lot of good work to encourage the Balinese traditions in art and culture to be taught to the local children. I have been to Bali a few times and this visit I finally went to ARMA - what an absolute surprise it was - so beautiful!
Authentic Bali art. Classical, modern and European styes and genres. Lovely, relaxing grounds. Now a UNESCO site. Don't miss it.

We enjoyed it!. Balinese are actually very talented. It was a great experience to visit the ARMA museum, the art pieces are beautiful. Once you're done just go opposite for lunch (Naughty Nuri's) If you enjoy art you will enjoy this place.

A great collection. Don't try do this all at once ,visit one Building first then have Lunch or a snack on the grounds , if you are lucky you might meet Agung Rai the owner in the coffee shop . Tell him Django sent you and he will entertain you . The museum is the best in Bali displaying paintings of possibly every Artist from the 30s to the 70s who painted here .
A Small Gem. Entrance fee is steep, but the gardens alone are worth it. The museum itself is modern and informative.

Great Art, Incredible Grounds. About a 30 minute walk from Central Ubud, this museum does not disappoint. The surrounding grounds, gardens and ponds are tranquil and peaceful. You get to enjoy a complimentary coffee or tea in an open air cafe, which is excellent. They have 2 buildings housing art, one is traditional balinese art and the other is more modern art. Both collections are very nice, plus they have a few other exhibits as well. A great way to enjoy a morning or afternoon in Ubud.
Worth seeing.. Set among lovely orchid gardens, the galleries are well worth seeing. I found the contemporary gallery interesting with more colour and life than the traditional paintings.

amazing Dance performances. I went to 2 dance performances during my stay in November, the Legong Dance and the Kecnak Fire Dance during full moon. It was amazing and felt so much more genuine and less touristy than opposite the Ubud market.

ARMA Museum. The ARMA museum is a must see when in Ubud. The restaurant is beautifully set and has delicious food. The museum itself has amazing works of art with a lovely little cafe where you receive a complimentary drink as part of the entrance fee. And to top it off the night time performances are exquisite.

ARMA, more than just a museum!. More than just a wonderful museum of Balinese & Indonesian art, the grounds are superb and they have a great cafe for a snack, coffee or a meal. They also have the Kecak dances here for full moons. It is a wow!

Tranquil, artistic oasis. I was very impressed with my visit to the Agung Rai Museum of Art (or ARMA as it is known). The collection comprises a beautiful history of Balinese art, including works by expatriate artist William Spies. The museum's buildings are set in a tranquil, picturesque Balinese garden and there is also a very pleasant cafe where one could while away an afternoon. I had the opportunity to meet Mr Agung Rai, who was strolling around the grounds, and he was very welcoming and full of interesting information. Definitely worth a visit!
Interesting art, gorgeous grounds. Very peaceful, perfectly manicured gardens surround numerous gallery buildings; admission includes afternoon tea.

Worth a visit. At 60,000idr (approx. 6aud) it isn't cheap in bali dollars, but worth a visit if you have a few days in Ubud and is actually great value. I'm not arty at all but, the paintings are quite lovely and there is about 350 to see over the two galleries. What really sold it for me was the lovely gardens that surround the museum, they are very beautiful so make sure you take the time to explore the grounds inc. the rice paddie fields. The entrance price also includes a complimentary tea or coffee in the café which is great. Just a tip, the museum itself is not air conditioned so consider going early to beat the heat

Love it!. Mr. Agung Rai, was one the most beautiful souls i have ever meet, we visit the museum and had the luck to meet him.We love how much you love and know about Mexican history and art, really appreciated the time you took to show us around!
Quite and beautiful. I felt like stay at the other from the other people , it was traditional art museum in Indonesia , restaurant was also nice , flower, lake , natural ,,,,,

Great collection, and grounds.... This museum is worth a visit. The collection is impressive, and the grounds are beautiful.The collections are really interesting and complement a visit to the Puri museum nicely. I didn't eat at the cafe but saw food coming out and it looked great. Also got to meet the founder which was very cool! He encouraged me to go explore throughout the property and it was a nice walk.

Tranquil Gardens and Lovely Art. One of my favorite stops on Ubud tour. We had to force our tour guide to take us there since he doesn't get a cut, but well worth it. The old architecture is fabulous and I wanted to sit in the gardens all day and listen to the fountains. The tea room is lovely and you can get a light lunch and a free tea or coffee is included in your ticket price. There is also an upscale resort that is part of this and you can get lunch there. The art is an array of foreign and indigenous artists and gives you a real understanding of what quality Balinese art is like.

Nice place for art lovers, not so much for the avg. person. ARMA is built in a nice complex and houses many paintings from Agung Rai's collection.While I enjoyed looking at some paintings, some were really detailed and pretty ... after a while it becomes a bit much. A true art lover would nevertheless enjoy spending time time in my opinion.I liked paintings by German painter- Walter Spies. I thought they were beautiful

Traditional Ubud charm. A relaxing break away from the busy and now very touristy streets of Ubud.Gardens a delight.Beautiful little girls training for Balinese danceCoffee/tea in charming cafe included in entry ticket

Excellent musuem!. Superb collection of Balinese traditional and contemporary art housed in beautiful buildings on acres of gorgeous garden. Don't miss this. Also enjoyed the children's Sunday 10am dance classes.

State of the Art. Beautiful grounds, impressive museum buildings and fantastic collection of Balinese paintings. Well designed exhibits showing the evolution of various styles of paintings and how they were influenced by western travelers after WW1. A must see museum in Ubud.

The one!. If you only wanted to visit one museum or gallery in Ubud, this is the one! An excellent collection of well displayed art from modern to traditional, it is situated in gorgeous gardens that run down a hill to a lovely river. The gardens are spectacular. Staff were kind and helpful.

A very special spot. There is no better place to visit to learn about Balinese arts and culture. The galleries are the vision of a single man with a passion for Balinese history and spirituality. Also on the grounds, there are a couple of eating spots, and accomodation. It seems an all-in-one stopping spot.
Great. A nice museum with good work and nice layout with outdoor space. Worth a visit if you're passing this end of town
Old and new paintings. The large collection of old paintings are not only a visual treat but lessons in Indonesian history as well

Nice mix of traditional and modern. Besides the art the grounds are stunning to walk through. The traditional art in the large museum building was impressive and showed a great background of Balinese history.
Terrific site. Lovely site and an interesting museum. The best in Ubud. Fun just to walk around the resort and experience how the wealthy live.

lovely way to pass a few hours. I enjoyed the displays of old and contemporary Indionesian art. It is a nice size, in that it isn't overwhelming or repetitive. The gardens are spectacular. Staff were kind and helpful.

Serenity away from busy Monkey Forest Road. This museum is worth a visit just for the rare orchid collection and the beautiful gardens. And then there is always the bonus of a conversation with the local Prince. Set aside half a day to take in all there is to offer, from the old Bali paintings to the great collection of contemporary art. Then there are the gardens to explore, a cup of ginger tea in the coffee shop and finally lunch in the restaurant. We can highly recommend the daily special. The very kind restaurant manager even arranged for us to be driven back to our hotel.

A total work of art. An educational display of beautiful traditional and modern Indonesian art as well as works by non-Indonesians of native scenes etc, and all set in buildings that themselves are lovely to look at, surrounded by quasi botanical gardens with lily ponds - the whole temple shebang. If part of the aim here is to tempt you into renting one of the holiday villas then it didn't work... I Will Re Sist....!

This is the one museum/gallery to visit in Ubud!. If you only wanted to visit one museum or gallery in Ubud, this is the one! An excellent collection of well displayed art from modern to traditional, it is situated in gorgeous gardens that run down a hill to a lovely river. There is so much attention to detail here and the flow of work makes it easy to learn something new about Balinese art. The gardens are full of beautiful trees and orchids, and there are pathways, ponds and bridges to explore. It's so peaceful - an excellent escape from the hustle and bustle.

The grounds are spectacular. The museum is really good. Lots of art that deserves appreciation. The hotel is pretty amazing, sprawling with individual cottages with private pools that look great from the outside (haven't stayed in them). The great thing for us is the grounds, stone sculptures, ponds, fountains, bridges, all in the grotty Bali style that is just sooo beautiful. Really a special place to stroll around outside and enjoy the surrounds, not to mention great for foto ops.Love it, a gem in a way hidden in Ubud, cuz you think "it's a museum". Go but maybe don't tell everybody!

Beautiful place to get away from the hassle. The museum is located between ricefields and has a very relaxed atmosphere. I am not the greatest art lover, but I really liked the traditional and modern Indonesian art (mostly paintings). It's very different from the European art, which made it so interesting. The gardens around the museum are beautiful, everywhere you look you see statues/flowers/ponds etc. They also give you a voucher for a complimentary drink (cold or hot coffee/tea) in the cafe with a beautiful view onto the ricefield.

The best art museum in Ubud. This private museum has it all in regard to both historic Balinese art and contemporary art by both Balinese and foreigners who have worked in Bali. Set in luscious gardens with labelled plants. Your entry includes an interesting booklet and a cool drink at one of two cafés.

an amazing afternoon at ARMA!. Absolutely loved the gardens and the villas here- spent 1.5 hours just walking around the grounds of the museum before actually going into the two main buildings to see the art. The art was really cool too, bc of the ability to see how art has evolved from the 1930s to present times. Balinese artwork is so intricate and detailed, and I spent a few hours looking at almost all the paintings. The modern building had an amazing piece called Golden Rice, which depicts ubud so well. HIGHLY recommend this- I definitely didn't want to leave! And the free coffee/tea voucher was a nice perk.

Real Balinese. nice garden, living culture in Ubud. there are cultural workshops, dancing, painting, carving with the children from the village. great concept that museum should be.i really like traditional paintings in the building. it is old, nice, many history behide, recommend

Great Experience!!. The museum was a great place to spend half a day or even a full day! The art was superb and not to be missed by art enthusiasts. It had a great variety of art and was a great place to learn more about the Balinese and Indonesian culture through the art and their descriptions. The entrance fee was affordable and goes to such a great cause to continue to keep the artistic culture alive in Bali. They offer some classes as well. I took the batik class and although it was great to experience. However, the instructor did not speak very much english so conversation was non-existant and asking questions was not able to be part of the process.

Fantastic gardens. This was the best museum we've visited in Bali - the grounds were beautiful and you can also walk around the ARMA resort which was lovely. The ARMA staff are also quite helpful (as are all Balinese) and helped us find the rice terraces and the village temple and school.

Fantastic museum, kids will enjoy too.. I visited the museum with my 1 year old and he really enjoyed it! Loved the statues, the outdoor sculptures, the indoor galleries (lots of colourful paintings and sculptures), trying out the gamelan, and a delicious light lunch in the cafe (there are a few cafes, we visited the one which entitles you to a free cold or hot coffee with your entry ticket- sat in a little raised pavilion and had fresh spring rolls, mushroom quiche and mango mousse).

ARMA museum and art center, Ubud, Bali. Everything was lovely -- the gardens, the buildings, the art, and the story of the man who built it. Lovely restaurant next door, too. Walking distance from mid-town.

Worth a visit. While am not a huge art lover, I saw this art museum recommended on trip advisor. Separate to the art collection which was extensive and diverse, the buildings that house the collection are worth a look also.The grounds and gardens are beautiful and there are plenty of orchids to view. I'm glad I took the time.

The best experience in Ubud. There are many attractions pushed on people when they come to Ubud but this art gallery surpasses any attraction you could see. The extensive grounds are phenomenal - a lush oasis of orchids and other exotic flowers. You enter a meditative state as you stroll through the Ubud that was and explore two buildings of exquisite art, a children's educational facility, ancient rice fields, and lush grounds. This could be one of the best experiences you have in Ubud. You may even meet up with the Director himself(as we did) as he casually strolls through the grounds of this excellent facility. A must see!

Beautiful (and expensive) art. I've bought from Agung Rai before when prices were a little more reasonable than they are today. Today, I can't really afford what they show, but their art is definitely top-notch and worth a look. Some of the pieces are so beautiful, I long to afford them and wish I could just ship them all home. I think ARMA is one of the best art studios in Ubud if not in Bali overall. If you are in Ubud, it's worth stopping by. ARMA is easy to find on one of the main roads.

Must see. The place itself is like a little heaven. the way through the gardens that lead to the rice field is gorgeous. The paintings are great if you are a big fan of indonesian arts as we are. It is in a quiet location, away from the streets and the cars. It seemed like a fresh break from the city's agitation.
very nice collection. We spent more than an hour inside the museum and then walked around the peaceful garden. The art display was amazing.

relaxing and nice walk around. We went there rather late in the afternoon and only had a bit over an hour there (after our driver mistakenly took us to another Museum of Art in the area). It offers a nice walk in a peaceful and settled garden, traditional Indonesian buildings, contemporary and traditional paintings. rice fields, hotel resort villas. simply a nice walk! We were not really into art but found the glances of paintings gave us a quick and broad but immense wonder of Indonesian cultural. I am still wondering why so many objects are cramped in a painting and often the distance dimension/perspective is not so much illustrated...Highly recommend those who like to walk in nature, don't mind to do a bit of art museum to go. For my teenage nephew, he found it was a bit boring.

Many collections but not many variety. It took us 1.5 hours to travel from Kuta to Ubud. Nice to see another area of Bali through the ride. Can see that this area is quieter and caters to tourists who seek the crafts & arts of Bali as the area is lined with wood crafts, art galleries & stone sculptures vendors. The art museum is not worth the travelling time invested because the variety is few, many of the same type--which is Bali inspired which depict Ramayana folklores & way of life in Bali. Seriously need some updates & proper maintenance. But the entrance fee is a mere IRD 60k, so don't expect too much.
Work of Art. The art works displayed were amazing. Worth visiting especially if you are an art enthusiast. Price was reasonable too !!

Good mix of traditional Balinese and modern art. Recommended to those who get "museumed out" easily, as it's a good one stop shop for Balinese art. First of all, the grounds themselves are beautiful - orchids that have been cultivated amongst the trees were a real treat to see in bloom. The exhibits are set in very impressive buildings, and we really enjoyed seeing some work by current, modern artists, as well as works by local artists throughout the last century. Very much enjoyed the Walter Spies exhibit in particular.

ARMA Museum and Resort = A hip arts hangout. ARMA’s pieces are from the private collection of Agung Rai and so the collection is not comprehensive, a little quirky, and includes reproductions (most notably the works of Walter Spies) that might put off some visitors looking for a more formally curated museum. However, there is a substantial collection of Balinese paintings and art starting from the 1940s as well as contemporary works housed on two floors in two large pavilions, so don’t be misled by reviewers who claim that there is nothing to see. For Rp 60,000, there is a substantial collection of Balinese paintings, a free drink at the museum café, an opportunity to stroll some of the most beautiful resort property you will find and also the chance to eavesdrop on any artistic events that may be going on when you are there. We lingered for several hours.ARMA is not only about its paintings. Judging from its promotional materials, it aims to be a hip arts community hangout where people can appreciate being surrounded by beauty however you define it and in our experience it succeeds. As we were about to enter the first museum building, we were directed by one of the friendly staff to first look around the grounds. The landscaping and architecture outside were as much a part of the experience, he said, and helped to provide a better understanding of the paintings inside. Sure enough, the grounds are stunning, with luxurious accommodations set amid tropical gardens and adjoining picturesque rice fields. As you look around, you will notice that some of the trees and flowers have been curated too in arboretum style with labels, just like the paintings, to keep you well-informed on your tropical flora. My wife and I admired the bridges, waterfalls, statues and exquisite displays of flowers and plants in the gardens and dreamed about which of the incredible rooms we would choose on our next trip to Ubud. I was quite taken by the two story open air bungalow set off to itself with stepping stones across what first appeared to be a lawn but what was actually a pond covered with finely textured water plants. Incredible.Finally, after passing through the museum, we were treated to music from the 2014 Ubud Jazz Festival. We had seen the signs all around town, but didn’t realize until we arrived at the museum that ARMA was hosting it, which made complete sense. Visitors should go to ARMA with the understanding that it is not your typical stuffy museum but a contemporary resort celebrating the beauty of the arts.
Beautiful local arts. Nicely presented local atrs in garden setting representing Bali culture. A few stairs to climb but worth the efort
Nice but limited access. Last minute decision , a convention was on so some of the building was closed .impressed by what I saw and the helpful staff

Beautiful gardens and interesting arts. Rp 60000 for admission and a complimentary drink. Gardens are beautiful. A lot of modern and traditional art works. Staffs are nice and friendly. They would tell you which way you should go to enjoy the best view without asking. Overall it's a good place to spend an afternoon. And the ice coffee is cheap but very delicious. There's also a resort inside which next time I go to Bali I would definitely stay in.
Interesting history. We enjoyed visiting the museum and got a great insight into the history and culture of Ubud. Some of the art was terrifying but simply amazing
Interesting Local Modern Art. interesting to spend a half hour at, $1 to get in and a refreshing iced tea included buildings a bit in need of updating

Beautiful gardens and fabulous art.. ARMA is located within a couple of beautiful building set in gorgeously lush gardens. The gallery houses some modern art, and is very different from the Neka Gallery. There is currently an area for Spies' work, which was interesting, and a number of other interesting art works. If you enjoy art, I would recommend going to both Neka Gallery and ARMA for the 'best of the old and new'.

Worth a visit. Good art gallery with contemporary art and another building with 2 stories of paintings. Really enjoyed it as the pictures depict Balinese life and it's religion. The grounds had many photo opportunities with coconut trees and other plants. The 60000 rupees ticket includes a free hot or cold coffee and tea at their restaurant. I had Babi kecap for lunch there. . Excellent. It was braised pork with sweet cili sauce. Pork was tastier and more tender than the famous Ibu Oka which I visited as well.
Worth a look. Has some excellent Balinese artworks that depict the way of life in Bali over time. The more contemporary pieces are no the greatest. Worth a look if you have some spare time in Ubud
