Nice Museum - Ubud Village Jazz Festival. We went there for Ubud Village Jazz Festival. Nice ambiance. Very clean. The toilets are well maintained and cleaned. Easy to reach by taxi as the location is in the center of Ubud.

Worth visiting. The museum is in a beautiful park with a stylish Balinese hotel/villa complex and a restaurant. The museum gives a nice overview of the development of the Balinese art over the last 100+ years. And the park (including a small rice field!) is just worth going there to relax and enjoy. Take your time!
Good gallery. Very nice gallery of paintings set in several buildings on extensive grounds. Well worth spending a couple of hours there.

Great museum compound. The balinese tradition of offering you a free drink bundled together with the museum entry pays off great here. The cafe faces a paddy field, so while sipping the drink we took a short nap under the pavilion which really rejuvenated us.

Lovely!. Beautiful, clean, elegant and lovely villa, great staff and perfect location.
We stayed in the Superior villa and it was such a romantic and private room with great pool and stunning outlook. The bath was great and the outdoor shower option fun.
Admission fee IDR60,000 per pax. Admission fee is IDR60,000 per pax with a complimentary drink in Warong Kopi (restaurant). Ambient is quite nice so it's worth it.
okay, but no must. It is a nice place with a lot of interesting art, both new and old. If you are not that in to art you can skip this place, but if you do I guess you will fint it worth visiting.

Worth it for the stunning garden, beautiful gallery.. If you are hankering for the real traditional Bali of old this experience is exceptional. I especially loved walking around the grounds which are like a mystical oasis of lush tropical gardens, rivers and water play.
Beautiful gallery. It is as beautiful inside as it is outside. Next to paddy fields. Very pretty gardens and buildings. Worth a visit.

Beautiful Setting.. It was great to see some art history of the Balinese because I was a bit clueless going in. Went to the two main buildings, one is dedicated to historical paintings from 1930's onwards and the other held the modern works.I was glad to see it but if you don't visit galleries or exhibitions back home then you probably won't get much out of this.If you do like art then you will not regret absorbing some traditional culture, beliefs and history by way of the ARMA.

Best of Ubud. After 3 months in Ubud last year, and 6 weeks in Ubud this year, ARMA museum remains my absolute favourite 'go to' place in Ubud. Even if you are not particularly an art enthusiastic, it offers a lot. As a place to relax and enjoy the beauty of Bali without leaving town...fantastic! Have a cup of tea and enjoy the museum grounds and surrounding rice fields. But do enjoy the artworks while you're there. Not a huge collection, but well considered, reflecting the development of a range of different styles in Bali over time, and the interactions between Balinese and European approaches. Check out a dance performance if you can...or have a chat to the very personable Agung Rai if he is there...he often is. In summary, a consistently lovely place to visit.

A lovely way to spend an afternoon. Extensive collection of beautiful traditional and modern Asian art from local and overseas artists housed in palatial galleries. The buildings are set in magnificent gardens with an extensive collection of named orchids.We had the pleasure of meeting Mr Agung Rai while strolling through the gardens .He was justifiably very proud of his gallery and heritage.A very knowledgable and pleasant gentleman.Highly recommended but allow a couple of hours at least to enjoy and soak up the ambience.Also if you have times stroll down though the resort and cross the river to view the rice paddies .
Nothing to see. I usually like to go in museum…but this one ??? Nothing to see, it's dark and hot in there. Happy I didn't have to pay to see that.

Fantastic site, do not miss if you are in Ubud. A friend recommended this museum, or I would not have thought to visit. Even then, my hotel in Nusa Dua said they do not get many guests asking to visit it, so I still wondered, but so happy I went! Gorgeous grounds and very interesting paintings in some very interesting buildings with amazing doors and "gates". We also walked around the grounds of the attached hotel which has a beautiful pool, villas and fountains as well as its own rice terraces. I wish I could have spent more time there, not to mention we practically had the museum to ourselves. For the inexpensive price of admission you get not only a small guidebook, but also a free drink at the lovely cafe where I also enjoyed a piece of cake. I just regret that I could not eat at the larger cafe near the car park or at their Thai restaurant, will do so next visit.Downtown Ubud streets were overrun with tourists and resembled a parking lot with cars barely inching their way the day we visited, don't spend much time there but visit this museum.

Beautiful gardens and Art. This place has the most amazing gardens and art. I was amazed t the breadth of knowledge here and the range of the treat/plants/staghorn variants and flowers growing in this museum/resort style area. Staff were very helpful too.

Thoughtful presentation. like: the traditional touches and free coffee at the splendid paddy field cafe. Mr Agung Rai's personal touch as he came up to us (and other visitors) to have a chat. dislike: Not putting the Spies paintings all in one section
Hidden treasure in Ubud, Bali. Liked the Palace Museum and Gardens. The hotel tropical gardens, the friendly staff and the good varied food.

Art art art. I liked the Art first but also it's historical sense about how Balinese art has become world art. A beautiful set of buildings and gardens. Great place in which to learn something and also relax

A great way to spend a day learning about Balinese culture. ARMA is Agung Rai's vision of a place that is designed to preserve the Balinese culture and way of life. It houses a wide variety of traditional and contemporary paintings by Balinese and foreign artists. The museum grounds are beautiful and capture the essence of traditional beauty in that, what you see outside you can find in the paintings themselves. There is also a resort, ARMA Thai Restaurant, Kafe ARMA, and Warung Kopi that have been developed to fund the museum.

Interesting gallery in lovely gardens. This art gallery is worth a visit. It is simply laid out in three stone pavilions set in lovely tropical gardens. There are interesting information signs beside each picture (in English) which tell the story of what is going on in the painting. Our daughter (aged 10) really enjoyed the stories and it was an interesting way to leant about the Islands heritage and culture. There is a cafe on site (which we didn't visit) and we enjoyed wandering around the Lilly ponds.
Enjoy. Nice collection of paintings in expansive grounds. Would recommend spending quite a few hours here. There are also exhibitions and a shop.

Agung is Aging -- but beautiful nonetheless!. I feel guilty admitting I'm not a Bali fan, but having been invited to a wedding I decided to give it another chance. Agung Rai Museum just might be one thing that could alter my opinion. The art itself was not that wonderful (particularly the disappointing Walter Spies), but the grounds, the gardens, the architecture and the liveliness of fulfilling Agung Rai's vision of creating a space to promote Balinese culture was totally enchanting. While we were there, we saw young girls learning to dance traditional Balinese dance, as well as a foreigner learning how to play the Balinese xylophone, surrounded by other gamelan instruments. We had drinks in the garden and while my fellow visitors felt the trees were all a bit overgrown, I marveled at the beauty of all these tropical trees, shrubs and flowers spilling over one another in an organically orchestrated way. It was truly enchanting -- and so very worth the visit!
Beautiful museum. Very nice open space with plenty of greens and nearby the monkey forest. Also possible to stay nearby the museum for more enjoyment!
Amazing Amazing. We were guided to walk around the lower part of ARMA by a nonchalant gentleman who we later discovered was Mr. Agung Rai himself. What a wonderful place to put together.

If you have spare time, but don't prioritise it.. Quiet museum, spent a quick hour tour there, was nice to see examples of different Balinese art, but perhaps would be better if you had a keen interest in art.

Cultivating local art and culture . This wonderful museum is a great attempt in preserving the local Balinese culture. They have done an outstanding job at putting a nice collection of paintings but have gone beyond just that, the architecture and the decoration of the sites allow you to understand even more about the identity of Bali. I found this visit to be one of the most interesting ones, not only for the art displayed but the history of the owners, the foundation and how it has evolved into what it is today. If you take 10 mins to read the first few pages of the guide they give you when you pay, the whole visit will be even more delightful.

Evening dance performance Satya Brasta. This performance at the museum is every Saturday night at 7:30. When I went it was not well attended. Probably an audience of 10 people or less. The dancers were mostly pre-teens. Skilled for their age, but still not polished. Good costumes, but not quite on a par with some other troupes. The gamelan orchestra was top notch.
Not extensive but worth seeing. Do check out the masks and costumes used for demonstrations of temple dance/dramas on the outdoor stage nearby

Didn't get it.. Have visited Art Gallery/collections far and wide, but felt this one was a little lost. Understood that it was an attempt to collect and display various styles from various era's, some early very good, as was some later stuff.Enjoyed reading a relatively comprehensive bio on Walter Spies (probably the highlight of the visit for me), but the biography was poorly lit, and incredibly small font.The biggest down side was that despite our visit at 10am, the heat inside was stifling, no air movement at all...

Careful with the bats. The food and the service were very nice but if you are scared of bats don't go there. There is a massive tree outside full of small bats they fly into the restaurant and swoop you. I hate bats so I didn't enjoy it. Couldn't wait to leave despite of gret food and ambience.
Very good. Nice open spaces to see a wonderful collection of Balinese paintings. Enjoyed it very much. Paintings from all schools are there.
Great Museum. The museum is not huge but there are a lot of interesting pieces of Art. Overal well maintained and really friendly staff.
Superb collection of traditional Balinese art. If you are interested in traditional Balinese art, this and the Neka are essential. The collection is superb and very well curated.
Great authentic experience. Nice and quiet, great scenery and a perfect distraction from the busy Ubud city. U also get a free drink to relax when u are done looking at the art and the old culture.

Surprisingly large collection. We were surprised by the size of this art gallery. Very interesting private art collection of mainly local artists, set in peaceful gardens with a comfortable coffee shop in a rice field setting. Don't miss this if you are in Ubud!

Museum and workshop. It was fun, I did an awesome woodcarving workshop.
The galleries were full of fantastic art.
There was a nice cafe with good iced kopi.
The map supplied was not very good, things were missing or had been added.

Enhances your Bali experience. Very soothing atmosphere of the natural environment, beautiful gardens and.... my highlight... it features a bronze statue of one high Indian spiritual master which you can meditate on while sitting on a bench.
a must to visit!. Great art and beautiful gardens. peaceful and relaxing. Also went to a Balinese dance there which was more authentic than others we had seen.

Holistic experience. Great collection giving a good overview of modern time balinese art. Set in a wonderfull scenery with gardens, water and Balinese culture. Thank you Mr Rai for your vission, passion and chairing all this.
Loved it. Beautiful art gallery. Amazing collection. Great to do on a rainy day. Admission price includes tea/coffee and 2 delicious cakes. They also hold a range of workshops. Highly recommend.

Fantastic experience - Tranquility and Creativity combined. There is an air of calm and serenity about this place, located only a road away from a busy street, but once your within its gardens it's as if your in a different world. The place is a mix between art within the walls - mainly painting and occasional sculptures (which are all beautiful) - and designs outside in the gardens. We spoke to a older gentlemen who worked there and he seemed so wise and at peace, he spoke of how the place was created to be in balance with nature, to be educational in a simplistic, creative and inspirational way. It is a place where even the old stone statues outside are 'painted by nature, glazed by moss'...Definitely visit and journey down to the river too! (Plus there is a Free drink included within the price of your ticket, well worth it at one of their beautiful and picturesque cafés)....

good selection of Bali art. Nice museum, fairly large selection of art covering several decades up to present day. Decent descriptions for most displays, can have a relaxing drink after in the restaurant, which is included in price of admission. Gives a very good overview of the development and evolution of art in Bali. Depending on how long you want to liner over the art, give anywhere from under 3 hours to half a day.

The dance show at the Agung Rai. Was not impressed with the dance show AT all. I would say the costumes were nice and the music soothing. But the dance and the actions of the characters were a good attempt at the best. I would def recommend the Fire dance at the kechak place in the city centre at Ubud market. Save ur 75 IDR.
well worth a visit. Something different, entry includes a drink! Art work is amazing and the setting is lovely. You can learn about the history of Bali here as well.
huge though small museum of an atmosphere. I love all there - exibition is not rich abut worth seeing ans it takes just one-two hours but one gets to know the essence of Balinese art

Amazing Agung Rai Museum of Art. The owner gave us a full walking tour himself - beautiful pieces of art equal to the beautiful grounds - a good 1/2 or 1/4 day visit, and don't forget to cool off with an iced tea in the cafe next to the museum!
Great. It has different art. You can also attend art classes in batik etc. a good experience as you get free coffee included in the entry

Spent little time - very warm and humid day - but impressive Museum. Good little cafe attached, and gift shop with some surprising merchandise! As I do not cope well with humidity, the lack of any aircon. was strongly felt.

Excellent museum and gardens with a unique atmosphere. We particularly liked the ethos of this museum in promoting Balinese culture and crafts and educating young people. The gardens have beautiful specimen trees and plants which are labelled for your information. We liked a lot of the art works by Indonesian and global artists. There is a pleasant restaurant and delightful staff to tell you about the exhibits. We just wished we had spent more time there, but hopefully can return in the future.
beautiful setting, nice collection. The staff is helpful, a huge art collection, beautiful grounds for a walk. I highly recommend this place.

A lively museum. I went there on a Sunday morning while my wife was enjoying a few hours at the spa ! When I got in , the first thing I witnessed was a group of youngsters learning traditional Balinese dancing from 3 lovely teachers . I stayed there for 20 minutes admiring the lovely moves under the sounds of a live band of 6 musicians . I then continued by following the recommended itinerary shown on the map given to me at the entrance and found myself in a beautiful environment of rice fields , gardens , river and buildings of Balinese architecture with music being played from an unknown origin ! I then went after one hour in this lovely setting to have a cup of cold coffee (included in the entrance fee ) noticing the preparations for a wedding ceremony to be performed later ! I learned from the waiter that normally there are some traditional dancing shows being performed on Sundays but it had been cancelled today because of the wedding ! My visit ended by a 2 hour tour of the Museum where both traditional and modern paintings are displayed in a very well organized setting and in a cool environment (meaning AC) ! A very interesting half day visit !

A live museum, an experience not to be missed. I was so lucky to be able to meet with the ARMA founder, Mr. Agung Rai. I could walk and sit with him for hours, listening to his lifetime experience, sharing his wisdom of life, explaining his vision of ARMA not just as a museum, but a living museum. All aspect in Balinese painting that you enjoy at his museum, comes alive when you spend sometimes outside the museum building, but within the museum compound. The light, the trees, the rice fields, the river, the children learning to dance... It's all there for you to experience with all your senses. Just A-M-A-Z-I-N-G!!

Great collection of okd and new. The location is close enough to Ubud city center so worth visit if you like culture. When we went, there were hardly anyone there so we had a nice leisurely tour. I especially liked the modern works, full of vibrant colors.

lovely peaceful place, great pictures. We found here at the end of a hot walk, entered the peace of a large garden and took the opportunity to have an iced coffee which was complementary with the entry cost (around $7au). Finding ourselves less than able to expend the energy we wandered around for a fairly short while and then treated ourselves to a long lunch perched high off the ground in one of the on site restaurants.We weren't satisfied with our performance (not enough looking) so returned first thing the next day to give it our best shot. The grounds were indeed peaceful and this time there was many artisans showing their creations and how they were achieved sitting within the gardens or in small pavilions. Leaving there we entered the world of what is Bali art, both historically and in its development over the last several decades. We found a lot to really impress and much to admire.If you are in Ubud, please take the time to look, it is well worth the attention, you may be even lucky enough to have a conversation with Mr Agung Rai.
Art museum in Ubud. A lovely museum of art and a quiet place to wander through the gardens and exhibitions also a nice little cafe attached which must one of the quietest places in Ubud

Amar museum, ubud, bali. The agung rai museum of art and arma resort in ubud, Bali is one of the most beautiful places on earth....it is a place of deep tranquility with unbelievable gardens and priceless art. ....I will go back many times.....not to be missed by anyone visiting bali

Worth the visit. I went after lunch time and its a very good way to spend part of the afternoon and also escape from the heat. The collection is so interesting, the buildings and the gardens very pleasent. You can see yourself in the balinese culture. Then you can go walking through the resort, a small river until the rice terrace. Very good time i spend there60 for the entrance and they offer you a coffee or tea

worth visiting if only for the gardens and cafe. fairly small art gallery, beautiful gardens... Entrance fee includes a coffee from the gorgeous cafe, but it's so gorgeous you might like to stop for lunch too

It is a must. A lot of paintings from 1900's era which show the unique Balinese style, so many details on the paintings. Next to the museums, there is a beautiful park which actually is part of the resort. We admired the scene very much. Don't rush your time of visit in this place

Worthy of a visit. Came by ARMA because I was supposed to go to a healer but the driver did not know where the location is. Since we were already in Ubod, we decided to be dropped off at ARMA. I have a neutral interest with museums but I enjoyed going there. The paintings displayed showed so much details that I could not helped but be impressed. We had some fun going around the galleries. I also liked the fact that they had this nice little cafe at the back with a very nice view of the rice paddies. The coffee came free with the entrance ticket. I ordered iced coffee and it was superb! Would recommend to those who love going to art galleries and museums.

A must-see, don't miss it!. If you have a moment to travel near Ubud, then this place is a must-see. The beautiful park houses two collections of art (in two separate buildings): One traditional Indonesian, and one more modern. Both are superb, and you will not regret any minute spent watching them. The park creates a great atmosphere to contemplate art and nature - it is more a sanctuary than a usual museum. The neighbouring resort intertwines seamlessly with the park - you can walk around little pagodas, rice fields, and pools - or relax with a drink in one of the hidden bars. Don't miss it!
go on a hot afternoon. This place is both interesting and lovely, and relatively cool. Ubud is a historical centre for colonial art and there are many fine works to enjoy.
Excellent for a rainy day. Beautiful gardens, nice architecture and paintings reflecting Balinese culture, in a way we don't see in shops.And there's a show (almost) every night.

A visit to ARMA is a must. I visit ARMA every time I come to Ubud and continue to enjoy the amazing collection of modern and traditional art. There is a new work there this year, a rice terrace, which is SUPERB. Free drink included in your entry and the coffee shop is a wonderful, relaxing, peaceful setting with lovely staff, the perfect place to contemplate the beautiful things you will see at ARMA.

Museum is my thing. Very good building. Very worth art museum. (Note only art museum) many painting. Mostly about village life and Hindu myths Ramayana and Mahabharata . I must mention that the art museum in Kerala India with a lot of Ravi Varma,s paintings are 100 times valuable. Not too many people so easy to stroll along. $6 entry fee which includes a $2 tea or drink.
Arma Museum. It has excellent local and regional art and is located in a beautiful compound that has a restaurant, wonderful garden, and talent show in the evenings.
Art and Culture. Brilliant way to get introduce to the local art and artist's work. History and Mythology of Indonesia.

Fabulous. Allow plenty of time. This is a beautiful museum where you could spend a lot of time. Wonderful selection of art, both historical and some more contemporary. The buildings and grounds are worth spending time exploring. Your admission includes a tea in the lovely restaurant.

Fantastic!. Beautiful. Stunning. Worth it! We actually can't imagine going to Bali without seeing it. The staff were very friendly & helpful, the museum is in a beautiful location. I would go back without hesitation!

Overrated. Should not be #1 Activity in Ubud. We came here at 530pm. Staff told us the museum is closed, although upon roaming their garden, we saw the museum door open and decided to stroll in. A different staff member tried to charge us 50,000rph for the remaining 10minutes. We declined and he said he could extend the hours to 630pm. As we caught a glimpse of the entire museum itself, we didn't it it was worth it. The grounds are beautiful tho, the trees are named with lovely flowers blooming. The most interesting piece for me were the doors to the museum.

Must see their fabulous collections. They have two building full of fantastic painting collections from old to newer ones. I love the Walter Spice collections… amazing!!! When you are done with the museum go visit their Warung Kopi. It is a tucked-away coffee place with a great dessert and drinks. When it is not full, choose to seat in the bale bengong next to the rice paddies area :-)

Interesting place. The museum has a wonderful garden with lots of orchids and fruits. You get a complimentary Ice tea/ coffee in the little warung kopi inside the museum which is very nice.The traditional section is very good, you get to see lot of traditional painting about myths and religion. They also have a smaller section of modern art.I was only a bit disappointed by the fact that is not very big.

A gem in Ubud. This sprawling cultural heritage site is filled with as much to see in the gardens as in the buildings. We had the pleasure of meeting with the owner and he explained that he wanted people to enjoy the gardens so he planned the space and the exhibits to attract people further into the property. It is stunning! On many levels, with fountains and lush gardens, sculptures and two buildings of Balinese art - one modern, the other original art.There is an excellent dining room on site, in a gorgeous setting, as well as accomodation - deep in the gardens and near the beautiful pool.This was a memorable day.

A must do Ubud experience. Each time we visit Ubud we spend a couple of hours wandering around this gallery in its gorgeous sprawling gardens. ARMA is committed to Balinese culture not only through art but also dance, history and discussion- so there are often other worthwhile events happening or promoted there. The extensive collection is stunning but also educational and gives a great insight into this amazing island and culture.

Too beautiful for words. While in Ubud, we visited the ARMA grounds five times and we couldn't get over how beautiful it was. The grounds are huge! The gardens are spectacular. There are Balinese ruins to explore, and the Watergarden was one of the most peaceful and serene places we'd found in all of Bali. If you don't visit ARMA you are doing yourself a great disservice.

Personal service from the owner. This is a lovely gallery in a beautiful setting. I met the owner who is often there in the garden (he told me he sometimes tells people that he is the gardener) who showed me around some of the more recent paintings in the gallery. A must-see, along with the Neckar Museum
Excellent survey. Lovely grounds and the separate galleries contain a wide range of wonderful paintings. Spend several hours here.
a bit boring. it was ok and the gentleman is to be admired for his work. The grounds are spectacular but the museum itself was not much.

Nice!. Love the decorations that they put outside of the museum, it is cute and perfect spot to take a picture!The place is very tranquil, and it is nice to spend a bit more time to stare at the paintings even I don't quite understand about art :DBut I love my visit there overall.

Definitely Worth a Visit !. This is a lovely place to spend a couple of peaceful and relaxing hours away from hustle and bustle of Ubud. The gardens are beautiful and the art collection varied and interesting. Highly recommended.

A garden oasis in the busy town of Ubud. We really enjoyed the gardens and buildings at the arma complex, views of the rice fields and the quiet location away from the busy main streets of town made this an enjoyable few hours. The permanent art display is wonderful, and with an ever changing visiting exhibition they is always something to see however often you visit. Entry includes a free drink ( tea or coffee) we took this at the Arma cafe and then stayed on for lunch.

Great visit, I will definitely go back again.. My husband and I enjoyed our visit at ARMA and it is one of our top activities experience in Ubud. The ARMA is actually a very large area right in the downtown Ubud which consist the art museum, resort, garden, coffee and restaurant area. The garden itself is lush and filled with artwork and beautiful landscape. The rooms/ villas seem very private and set in beautiful surroundings. I plan to stay at least one night in ARMA resort at least for one night so I can relax in the garden and check out the museum again. The museum itself is also very impressive. We learned so much about Balinese art and culture through looking at different paintings the museum has for exhibition. The entrance ticket includes one drink at any of the three cafes onsite. We enjoyed our Iced coffee surrounded by rice field, status, artifacts and birds. It was such a relaxing moment. Highly recommend to allocation a good 2 hours there to enjoy the beauty ARMA has to offer.
Great variety and breadth of collection. Vast enormous space and fantastic array of Balinese and other contemporary art - really priceless collection.

nice. this museum is ok if u have nothing to do anymore.. its ok for 1 visit but price could b cheaper..i think its was 70.000 .price a bit high.the garden was nice. also they have thai restorant there to eat,
Wonderful. Lovely place to visit - the gardens are exquisite, the art is amazing and one can spend hours in this place.

Unexpected Discovery. We visited ARMA out of curiosity. It was quite a pleasant discovery. The gardens were lush and filled with unexpected artworks, which was a delight. The entrance fee included a drink at their coffee shop: either tea or coffee and we had iced coffee. A perfect foil for the heat. What really took my breath away was the featured artist this month of February, Jan Peter Van Opheusden. I just couldn't get enough of his paintings. I wanted to photograph some of his works but signs said no picture taking. I was so happy his books were available for sale at the museum. Their brochure also mentioned 2-3 hour classes in batik, silver jewelry, Balinese architecture, dance and so much more. Just perfect for short stay tourists.
Excellent venue for events. The museum is beautiful but the green gardens around are excellent. The Ubud Jazz Village Festival 2013 took place in it and was a pleasure to be right there.

Wonderful Gardens. The museum is interesting and houses a lot of paintings and some woodcarving. The best thing about this place, however, are the gardens. Take time and wonder around and enjoy that magic secret garden atmosphere that is so typically Ubud!

A place built with love and passion. The museum presents a good size collection from authors that contributed to spread the richness of Bali (mainly painting and photograph). The museum is also a resort (one of the most beautiful and peaceful I have seen) and offers some traditional dances like the Kecak fire dance.
STAY HERE!. The rooms are gorgeous, the owner polite and super helpful, the grounds are incredible and the prices are reasonable.

A brief history of Balinese art. Like the name suggests, this museum houses paintings, both traditional Balinese and modern. The entry fee seemed a tad expensive, but the museum delivers what it promises - housing paintings from the early 1900s through to modern times and themes.I wonder if it would be good to have a guide to the paintings, as many of the themes are specifically Hindu, especially in the older paintings, and I couldn't help but wonder if I had missed out on the essence of some of the paintings that weren't about mundane subjects.The museum also houses a lot of Walter Spies' work. Also, a ticket to the museum gets you a complimentary tea/coffee by the paddy fields at Warung Kopi.Works of Paul Husner are being housed at ARMA right now, and in my opinion, are a spectacular window into the Balinese way of life.

A beautiful way to spend 2 hours even if you dislike art!. This visit fitted well with our girly trip to Bali. The gardens of the Museum are beautiful with a true Balinese feel. We are not great Art fans but this did not affect our experience. Instead we spent time admiring the building and tranquility of ARMA.

Truly an arts centre in Ubud. I have always liked ARMA but I had a couple of special treats this trip. I visited the exhibition by painter Paul Husner and loved his work. I sometimes think of ARMA as its permanent collection of more historical paintings and art work but this exhibition also shows that Mr Agung Rai is also on the forefront of art in Bali.And I also happened to be there on a full moon night and watched the special version of Kecak performed by Cak Rina dance. The setting and choreography by renowned choreographer Sardono, was truly stunning. It was definitely a cut above the other Kecak dances in central Ubud and in Uluwattu.
Art galley and museum. Located within the grounds of the Arma resort. Mr Agung Rai has preserved some of the best of Balinese traditional paintings. Must see.

Too Many Paintings. The entry was expensive and then again how many paintings can you keep looking at? there also has to be a story connecting all of them - or they have to be arranged progressively according to the story that have.. it was arranged randomly..
Good gallery. A beautiful estate with a great collection of paintings - not of the first rate like Neka - but still good. Interesting classes and activities going on.

events at Arma. Arma Museum is a wonderful place whilst an event is happening! Without a doubt we will be at any opening, Everything well prepared and catered for. Also a venue for Bali spirit festival, which works perfectly.! Great for art lovers, collectors, and artists! Three cheers for Arma

Impressive collection of art. At about $7 AUS this is a great place to visit. The art is split in to four different building with pre-war, post war and modern art being represented. A good place to spend a rainy afternoon as we did. The presentation was terrific and informative and took a good while to get through making this good value for money. The grounds were magnificent and we had the added surprise of being provided with Balinese cake and a drink included in the price.If you want to see some really good Balinese Art do not miss this
average. worth the experience, but for me the gardens were more interesting than the museum itself. Also the restaurant inside is really nice.

Whoa! what a gem.. When in Ubud, and for the meager price of $AU5.00 this is a must stop for those into art, culture and history. The site is huge and take time to see it all making your bang for buck good.
a must when in Ubud. It was an uncrowded art gallery with must see ground giving an insight into recent Balinese art and photographic history.

For lovers of art and local history . The gardens and the setting here are truly bali.
The gallery isn't as large as you would think however the art on display is quality
We had our driver explain the meaning behind a lot of the paintings. Which was very informative to the religion and local history
They have really good classes for art and dancing

Enjoying ARMA. Atmosphere and aura inside the compound were quite cool, calm and yet energizing. Collections of early Bali original paintings, influences of western painters (spies/smit/blanco/etc), to recent painting styles (young artist/penestanan/batuan/etc) are very complete to be enjoyed and learned from.

An oasis in Ubud. A nice place to take a break from busy Ubud. Peaceful and beautiful gardens and a pleasant cafe which serves complimentary coffee as part of the $5 entry fee. The art collection was interesting, although nowhere near as impressive as that at Neka. Definitely worth a visit.

Overrated. I went to ARMA with family including an infant who gets restless quickly. We buzzed through much of the museum which mostly seemed to be limited to two buildings and the well-manicured grounds. I liked most of the paintings but it was a bit sad how poorly they are curated with the hot, humid air exposed to all the works. Many of the works were very recent with some on display only having been painted this year. We thought there was much more to the museum but a lot of it is just the resort, restaurant and other enterprises. Although there were some super cool paintings, I wouldn't really bother unless it was a rainy day. We didn't stay to get the coffee that comes with admission as we needed to rush to the Monkey Forest Sanctuary before naptime.

Definitely Worth a Visit. This is the best museum in Ubud. With the price of your ticket you get a free coffee in the lovely cafe which in it self is worth a visit. The grounds are beautiful with flowers everywhere. There are two floors of paintings, mostly traditional Balinese, a few foreign painters that came to Bali to paint. There are no original Walter Spies here only copies.

More Than Just A Museum. I was more impressed by the botanical gardens and how every plant is labelled with more information than you could ever need - very educational - even with something of a botany background. The grounds are quite well done and spread out, great place for a relaxed walk exploring all of the various parts to the museum and its associated resort complex.

Very Worth A Visit. ARMA MUSEUMMy first visit ever to Ubud would be meaningless if I did not step into any arts museum. The time constraint urged me to prioritise two museums; one of them is Arma. The Rp 50,000 (US$ 4.2) entrance fee did sound “wow” but not anymore once I’d been in its complex and painting museums. I do admire its well maintained vast complex a tranquil sanctuary with strong Balinese architecture and landscape; and later I learn that it is often chosen the venue of world class events. Its marvelous orchid collection tickles me to spend some time admiring them. Two carvers were commissioned onsite (in a designated pavilion) to work on crafted doors. Lucky me … I had the chance to talk to them and gave a try. It turns out that carving is not that easy (at least for me). Lovely paintings of famous local (Balinese and Indonesian) and foreigner painters (painting Indonesian topics) are nicely displayed. I was very attracted to the “Nobleman” painted by Raden Saleh (Indonesian painter - and “Calon Arang” by Walter Spies. The latter, a Javanese/Balinese folklore, was greatly depicted by this German painter. Amazing……If I get a chance to go to Ubud again, I will spare more time to admire its collections. It is very worth a visit.

Neighbours. As we are neighbours of the Museum and have a clear view on the evening performances one could see us as connoisseurs of the museum and especially the dance pavilion. We know Bali very well. But there is simply no place on Bali where you can see this high quality of dance performances, in an enchanting entourage.The museum is worth a visit as well, if you like paintings and if you know a little bit about Bali's special painting styles. The museum has some very rare pieces of Walter Spies and many examples of the 'young artist' style that he introduced with his pupils. And if you can sneak through, take a walk through the Agung Rai Resort and it's beautiful garden.
Tranquil retreat. A shady, tranquil retreat from the bustling street with an intriguing, eclectic art collection, beautiful gardens and pleasant tea-rooms.

ARMA is important effort, but could be much better. First encounter with Balinese art made this visit special, but the presentation is very far from perfect. Do not expect Spiess originals. There are only Spiess reproductions which were all blueish because of the years exposed to light. Pitty because a museum like this has potential. Specially because there is a nice garden around the museum.

A must see. We were given a free trip and a free shuttle ride as part of our Sungu hotel booking . The modern art is fantastic and apparently all the vistors to Apec were taken there and probably bought something but for us we just looked. It was fabulous and a privilege to see. Art always gives you an insight into culture and the guide who followed us the whole way was able to answer our questions if we wanted him to.

Agung Rai - Another Great Art Museum. Nice collection of Bali art housed in two two-story buildings. Included works by artist Walter Spies. Beautiful estate grounds with dozens of blooming orchids and sculptures (Oct 2013 visit).

Fantastic galleries and a lovely guide. Really enjoyed visiting ARMA, fascinating insight into the history of Balinese art right through to contemporary installations...Fab cafe and beautiful gardens.

Fun Wood Carving Workshop. I took a two hour wood carving workshop. Wood carving is very tough and you have to be okay with your hands hurting afterward. The instructor was very helpful, though he would lose concentration sometimes. The museum like beautiful even though I didn't get a chance to look around much. It worth a visit. If you're a student, bring your ID and you'll get a discount.

Well worth a visit. Interesting insight into Balinese past through a good selection of paintings. I also liked a lot the beautiful paintings of European Walter Spies, who lived in Bali in the first half of the 20th century.

I don't like museums, but this place is something else. I usually skip art museums. I am not going to tell you that I looked at every art piece carefully. But I did enjoy the ones I stopped by to see. Most importantly, for me, is the excellent museum housing and beautiful surrounding gardens.

Art with a leisurely stroll. This is a must-see, art-orientation for anyone's first visit to Ubud.You might like to stroll the grounds of the hotel complex next door, with its lush gardens and a 'display village'. Great photo ops here.

Great galleries to visit!. Two wonderful galleries with contemporary and traditional Balinese art. The gardens are magnificent with plants individually named for budding botanists. Highly recommended to view when visiting Ubud.

ARMA Agung Rai Museum. What an amazing place! A must see for all visitors. A garden of Eden with rice fields and a fantastic collection of Balinese art and its history within walking distance of the main street of Ubud. The staff were extremely welcoming. We were lucky enough to meet the curator of the gardens who has lived in the area for 7 generations and was a wonderful ambassador for the place. It has a true feeling of serenity.

Outstanding contemporary art and grounds. There are two buildings of art - one contemporary and one traditional. I loved seeing the contemporary art being produced now by local artists. The grounds are amazing. I was delighted to get a glimpse of two lessons: gamelan instruction for boys and legong dance instruction for girls. It was a nice peek into Balinese culture being perpetuated by the younger generation.

Highlight of Ubud. High quality Indonesia art in a beautiful setting. I think this was the best of the Ubud museums. Although I didn't see any of the performances this is the place to go for authentic Balinese dance and music. There is a nice outdoor garden and tea shop, and the rice fields are right behind the grounds.

Superb Balinese art in a beautiful house and gardens. Once you get inside ARMA and the gardens, the noise of the world outside vanishes and you are in an oasis of art, culture, plants and water features. If you are lucky you will see a Balinese dance class as well. There are permanent displays of some of the best examples of classical and contemporary Balinese paintings. There are temporary exhibitions, too. We saw a special exhibit of the art of Walter Spies, the German painter who lived and loved Bali but died when his ship was torpedoed by the Germans in 1942. There is a very good cafe in the gardens..you will get a free tea or coffee as part of your 50,000 rupiah entrance fee and there are good drinks and snacks for sale, including cakes. At night, gamelan and dance performances are held in the gardens of ARMA. We saw Topeng on a Wednesday night.
Lovely setting. Really interesting and beautifully maintained. This is an interesting Art museum with some well explained exhibits. I liked the cafe -great view.
favorite museum in bali. this special museum in the heart of ubud is some of the best in historical art mixed with modern balinese painters. gorgeous grounds.
Very interesting and a nice change. A good museum of local art and encouraged me to search out some lesser pieces I could take home with me.
Enormous buildings full of treasures. You can walk for hours and not see it all. Mr Rai collected pieces from all over the world for our enjoyment. Be sure and see all of the buildings.
Worth a visit, pricey though. Traditional Balinese exhibit on one of the floor, bit disappointed as the rest are merchandise items as exhibit

Lovely and gracious museum--and free afternoon tea!. This lovely museum features a full history of Balinese painting, including several older pieces that predate the arrival of William Spies and Ralph Bonnet in the 1930s. The grounds are lovely. We found we tired after awhile of all of the traditional Balinese themes (Ramayana pictures, lots of Barong pictures), but our favorite part of the museum was the contemporary section. One of the highlights is a massive 'painting' that is actually a multi-media exhibit--a huge representation of rice fields at harvest, with the rice stalks, etc., consisting of melted strands of colored fibre. A wonderful bonus for the foot-weary traveler is the gracious afternoon tea that is supplied with your entrance fee. The Warung Kopi served beautifully decorated lattes and cakes, and we were seated cross-legged on airy, roofed platforms overlooking the adjacent rice fields. Fantastic!
Eclectic art in an idyllic setting. A lovely visit in ubud. The art on display is fantastic and varied. The setting in which the museum sits is just as brilliant- wonderful gardens!
best gallery museum in ubud. best gallery museum in ubud, is a traditonal building and a great resort to. i will like to suggest anyone to come here.

A great gallery in a beautiful setting. We were delighted with our visit, seeing both Bali art, and modern art. The setting is great too - both the main gallery and the grounds.
We were delighted to meet Mr Rai who gave us a tour of part of the gallery and took us to coffee.

Fantastic overview of traditional Balinese Artwork. We were lucky enough to visit whilst there was also a contemporary exhibition on at the gallery. If you are interested in genuine works of art you must visit ARMA whilst you are in Ubud!

Don't tell a soul. Agung Rai is someone incredibly special.
His museum is worth spending time in but his hotel is even better.
His love of his land is a joy to behold and great opportunity to learn.

Fantastic Music at the Jazz Festival. It was the best trip to Ubud to date having been there before.This time we were there for the jazz festival at ARMA. Food was good too. For 500,000 for 2 days of music culture plus free flow of local (plaga wine) from 7pm to 10pm.The entrance fee is reasonable. The music was well worth the trip and money. The last evening on Saturday, Peter Beets trio played to our heart and soul. He was an entertainer and a musician.A musician play his own music but Peter wow the crowd! His mastery of the piano...wow! like magic fingers...smooth as silk.We truly enjoy his music. The rest of the musicians are also great. Most local talent and we believe Indonesia have many talented people and artists. The government need to sponsor more such events.There was another band that fuse western and traditional Balinese instruments and it was just the perfect match. Bali should win a prize for creativity. Bali should be cited as world heritage just for her people alone; warmth and talented...is there such an award? the thais are friendly and hospitable but Balinese, warmth and talented...in every aspect of art...stone, wood, silver...you name it and they have it...;)Now, we will visit the jazz festival again if it is organised next year.You should go too. Well worth the trip to see so many musicians playing so many different kind of music under one roof!

gives an idea of ​​the modern and traditional painting Bali. be sure to visit a master class in drawing, and better to be in a long-museum atmosphere of harmony and tranquility, a wonderful restaurant with private verandas, beautiful well-kept grounds of the museum will add pleasant sensations.

Surprisingly good. We visited this museum during a day trip around Bali and were very pleasantly surprised by the place. There was a combination of traditional Balinese sculptures and paintings as well as contemporary art. The location is beautiful with rice fields on one end and big gardens surrounding the museum galleries. There were different arts and crafts that you could take part in. The entry fee is relatively expensive compared to what you'd expect to pay in Bali but you get a complimentary drink at the coffee shop. Worth a visit!!

A pleasant way to pass an afternoon. The museum was quite interesting and educational. The grounds were lovely and then there was a free cold drink when we were finished. A pleasant afternoon but not a must see.

Very small, not very thorough explanations. I went to the Agung Rai, Neka and the Puri Lukisan museums in Ubud. None are stellar, in my opinion, but this one was my least favorite. Its fairly small and you can see it in about one hour. Felt a little commercial since they had art for sale in one part. Needed more explanations of the art periods and artists.

I Regretted Paying the 50,000Rp/pp. It's really hard to judge an art museum based on TripAdvisor reviews, and our hotel was so close to ARMA that it seemed a shame not to at least try it. Well, we tried it, and for 100,000Rp for us as a couple, I was really disappointed. The grounds are lovely, but the actual artwork in the museum buildings was forgettable. There were quite a number of contemporary art pieces for those who enjoy that kind of thing.

Don't miss it.. Actually got to meet Agung Rai. He and his wife are the epitome of Balinese graciousness. ARMA is a credit to their love of Balinese art and history. A must-see, EVERY time you visit Ubud.

Disapointing Museum. The grounds and structures are lovely but many of the paintings on display are reproductions. There are also some massive paintings that belong in the lobby of a western office building. They do include a cold drink in the price of admission.
Great food and service. The servers were great, very helpful. The food was yummy, we ate there a few times during our stay. The art and the fire dance performance were also very cool.

Worth visiting!. We really enjoyed having a look around all the artwork in this museum and met Mr Agung Rai in the garden, which was very nice.It was great to see some contemporary work here as well as some great historical Balinese art too.

The grounds are worth the price of admission, the art is a welcome bonus!. Home to a performing arts center, the ARMA houses an extension collection of classical and contemporary Balinese art. Raden Saleh's "Portrait of a Javanese Nobleman and his Wife" from 1837 is captivating, and has an interesting restoration history. Walter Spies "Calonarang" is engaging and an original, but the rest of his work here is all reproductions. The "Not For Sale" mixed media work is thought provoking and timely, given Bali's struggle to balance environmental protection with development. The grounds are relaxing and beautiful, dotted with sculptures.

BEAUTIFUL SETTING & GROUNDS. I am aware of four art museums in Ubud and have visited all of them. They are all good and well worth a visit, but I think this one is my favorite. The entry fee of $5 is well worth it and includes a free tea or Bali coffee in their restaurant. The grounds include an upscale hotel that certainly appears nice.The artwork itself is housed in two large buildings, with both modern and classical Balinese works of art. A nice way to spend an hour or two...
Wonderful gallery. Well worth a visit. Set in beautiful gardens. Pre and post-war Balinese art. Lovely café overlooking the gardens.

Balinese art and gardens. A fine collection of Balinese art and paintings of Bali by foreigners in a private museum located in beautiful gardens. A very good introduction to the impressive styles of local painting. The owner may be wandering around and will introduce himself to visitors! The café, with a complimentary drink, is very pleasant, and the shop sells top-quality textiles - much better than found in most Ubud tourist shops.

enjoy the peace, stop for tea and why not a massage?. a peaceful interlude in your Ubud trip. wander around the buildings and gardens, stop for a really nice lunch and try the massage, it is well worth the slightly higher cost!

Wonderful atmosphere and nice collection of paintings!. The museum is embedded in a lovely park that just oozes peace and tranquility. Slightly outside of town in Pengosekan, it is home to a nice collection of Balinese art, or rather, art about Bali. Center pieces of the permanent exhibition are one work of Raden Saleh and one wonderful little piece by Water Spies. Ticket price is high at 50k per person, but includes a free (ice/hot) coffee or tea at the Warung Kopi of the museum. Well worth the trip, I loved it!

A JOY TO VISIT. ARMA has a great collection of local painters work plus a colection of historical pieces from famous Spies, a famous expat artist from the 30's. It's a lovely museum also with gardens and incredible Balinesian buildings and well worth the small entrance fee.

Good spectrum of art. A good collection of both traditional and contemporary Balinese art in a pretty setting with some interesting architecture. It was very quiet during our visit so you can really go at your own pace. Guides were available upon request, but you can easily explore on your own as the write ups are also all in English. There are some very impressive pieces here and it is home to a great collection of Walter Spies. A nice way to spend an afternoon.
Interesting museum. what a great place to see indonesian art and artefacts, great facilityFood amenities there iare great

The best of Ubud. The Agung Rai Museum of art is the best thing to see in Ubud. Unfortunately, few people goes there even so it is located very close to the city center, definitively walking distance. This place is the dream come true of Agung Rai, it is the most beautiful place, its ground, its rice fields, bridges, resort, etc.., it is ART. Everything is there for a reason and nature has been brought into the very heart of the museum. The museum itself displays the most incredible paintings that shows a link between the landscape, culture and religion. DO NOT MISS THIS PLACE.

interesting place to visit. Worth visiting to see the modern art collected by Arung Rai- extensive collection. Nice cafe with pleasant atmosphere. Had lunch at the Thai restaurant and the villas next door look inviting

Not worth the walk. May be the timing wasn't right, but all we've seen were paintings and some reproductions. They seemed nice, but no guide was available. The booklet they gave us was full with platitudes about their vision and mission, so not very helpful.We haven't seen any workshops or classes.They need to invest a bit more effort to make the visit more pleasant: clearer maps and signs (the places is BIG), offer guided tours, etc.
Beautiful Bali art work. Beautiful Balinese art work from traditional to contemporary artists. The grounds as well are wonderful to walk through.

beautiful place. This very beautiful museum is a series of buildings filled with traditional Balinese art. The grounds, buildings, and art are all stunning. During our first visit, we got to talk to wood carvers working on beautiful wooden doors, and watch a children's dance class. On our second visit, we'd signed up for a batik class from Deking, which was very fun and interesting.

Contemporary Art in Bali. This well set up museum in several buildings set in beautifully landscaped grounds has a good collection of modern and contemporary Balinese art. The week I was there, a special exhibition, "Irony in Paradise", opened, accompanied by an excellent bi-lingual brochure, explaining the genesis of the art. The art shown was political in nature, showing that not all the artists in Bali make images of rice paddy scenes, half-naked locals and elaborately costumed dancing figures. A free beverage is offered with admission.

Beautiful. Beautiful artwork on beautiful grounds! The stone work around the museum gardens is stunning and the natural beauty is something to see in itself. The art is really representative of Balinese culture and is definitely a style all its own. The resort is incredible and relatively inexpensive (in terms of U.S. prices, a bit pricey for Bali rates)
At and nature combined. Fantastic gardens and architecture, carvings and stone work. Displays showed both modern and traditional art works. Could have spent more time there but we only went in late.

All By Myself. I was the only one at the museum on the day I went. The building is very impressive and the art work just beautiful. It's wonderful to see that the Balinese are looking after just valueable, historical works of art.

Informative, excellent collection, beautiful surroundings. The art collection here is second to none, showing a huge variety of Balinese art from across the years. It is also set in the most beautiful gardens, making it a pleasure to walk slowly around, stopping for a drink at the end. The galleries have fans but no air-con, so do take your time and wander slowly. There is quite often a display of woodcarving or similar local craft in the grounds, so it is worth checking out what's coming up.

Excellent Balinese museum. This is a fantastic museum of Art. The grounds are kept beautifully and the artworks are well looked after in lovely pavilions. It cost 50000 to enter, which includes a free tea or coffee at the coffee shop, which i think is a bargain for the quality of the art gallery. The museum is very easy to navigate yourself. And the best thing is no guides harassing you to show you around or for money. You really could spend hours here, it is so peaceful. Highly recommend this place to others wanting a bit of Balinese culture. It's a shame other museums/art galleries in bali don't follow this one as an example.

Peaceful spot in the center of Ubud. This place is fuller of greenery, peace and art. The atmosphere is very peaceful. You could spend time here for 2-3 hours. Another art space that you should not miss in Ubud.

Culture & beauty. I enjoyed a lovely day at the Museum, spending hours walking around viewing the gorgeous artworks. I stopped for lunch at the Warung Kopi on the grounds, enjoying a delicious meal while lounging on the daybeds. It was a great way to spend a few leisurely hours in beautiful surroundings. I left feeling educated and peaceful.

Everything was great.. We stayed at the Arma resort within the grounds of the museum and cultural/art centre for nine days. While we were there we watched many stage productions, did the wood-carving course, the batik course, offering making and painting. We are so glad we did these activities. They have enriched my memories. Don't miss the afternoon Mysticism tour (or the 6am morning one - too early for me). You really find out the real Ubud not ten minutes from the museum.

best cultural experience in Ubud. a world of music , art and dance , in the middle of buzzling Ubud , a world away from bemos and motorbikes...spend days here watching artists at work,joining them in workshops and watch performances as well as a gallery that hosts the most beautiful paintings in Bali

Beautiful museum and grounds.. This is a beautiful museum with a good mix of art, statues, gardens and nice walking paths. I spent more time than I would have imagined here. It's a peaceful place to view art and escape from the crowds and tour buses. They also have a great outdoor cafe to relax (more for drinks than food I think) and the staff throughout the museum are very friendly. The also offer classes which I saw taking place. If I'd been in Ubud longer I would have looked into them!
Interesting collections. Well laid out art museum with good stocks of local artistry. The operators probably pay commission to the taxi drivers and bus tour drivers, so beware of prices.

Beautiful art gallery. This was my intro to Balinesse art which I fell in love with. The gallery buildings themselves are beautiful as were the gardens in which the gallery is set. Reasonable to get in, especially as there was a drink included. Would highly recommend.

A Must See. Be sure to experience the art and history of Bali and its legendary icon, Agung Rai. Tour the grounds, or better yet stay on the grounds of the island's jewel of a hotel and restaurant adjacent to the galleries.

Leisure museum/park. Such great place that houses a number of traditional & modern artworks. It has a garden too, so serene, so green, you can sit there for hours. Perfect spot to wander around alone.

High point of our visit to Ubud. Sat in on a sketching class, where we also watched children's dance and gamelan classes. Also several traditional artists were demonstrating their craft. Beautiful grounds, wonderful museum. A great introduction to Balinese culture and history.

Be sure to ask for Francois "The Gardener". Our host, Nyoman at Nirvana Homestay in UBUD recommended we drop by ARMA. Nyoman designed the gardens at ARMA. He mentioned that we might get lucky and run into Francois "The Gardener." Sure enough, we did. Francois gave us a grand tour of the grounds and galleries. He treated us to coffee at the cafe and was extremely generous with his time considering how extensive the gardens are and how much work it must be to maintain them.We returned to Nirvana that afternoon and told Nyoman we'd met Francois. Nyoman replied with a rolling belly laugh... Francois is in fact Agung Rai, the founder of ARMA!I've since returned to ARMA 4 years after this first tour and Francois remembered me and once again showed me around and gave of his time.WONDERFUL place, experience and a memory of a lifetime.

a must. if you are interested in Bali culture and art, there is not much better place that this. Many people just want to party in Bali but if you are there for more than that, you cant go wrong at the ARMA.

real highlight of Ubud. beautiful museum, great art and the villa accomodation that we walked through looked stunning.We also had the good fortune to meet Mr Rai himself. he has an extraordinary personal story to tell and he is clearly a charming and charismatic man as well as a great philanthropist with a great love of Bali and its culture.Highly recommended

Tradition in beautiful surroundings. This place is amazing to while away a couple of hours away from the hustle of Ubud. The artwork needs to be seen to be believed, with ultra-contemporary work alongside more traditional offerings. The history lesson is worth it. If you tire of walking around, head over to the restaurant with its great food and drinks and gorgeous little eating huts where you can lounge back on cushions and take in the rice paddy view. Lovely!

meeting with a master. spent several hours sitting in the rain and drinking tea with Agung Rai...an amazing human being...he is a poet of architecture and landscape and a great friend of the local craftspeople

Amazing place. This was the site of the Ali festival(?) last year. There was everything about it to like! The Bali spirit festival is the proper name of this annual event, we observed that many people there were yoga enthusiast.

Good introduction to the different art styles. This museum is well presented in several different building - each tending to represent a period/style. Enjoy the calm of looking at art without a vendor in tow.

Although beautiful, less informative than Neka or. What's not to like? This recently built museum is in a beautiful setting, a guide will greet you, give you a (not very helpful) "guidebook" and likely escort you through the exhibits. Admission includes a drink at the garden bar, there's a carver working in a central pavillion, they have their own dance troop and offer classes in Balinese dance, art and I think even cooking. The attached resort grounds are spacious, and there's a gift shop, so you can pass a very pleasant couple of hours.The art collection, extensive as it is, with European works inspired by Bali as well as Balinese, is not well curated. (Some works do rotate, as the owners of this museum are gallery owners.) The collection does not have the same breadth, depth, historical perspective or importance as those at the Neka and the Puri Lukisan in Ubud. So if you only visit one museum, I'd chose one of the others. If however, you love museums, this is not one to pass up.
Worth a trip. Lovely museum on gorgeous peaceful grounds. Just a 10-minute drive outside of central Ubud. Beautiful Balinese art (that no one is trying to sell you!)

Very peaceful; a good break from the hustle & bustle of Bali. When entering the museum, we were each given a voucher for a coffee and a guide book (on paying the fee). We then entered the peaceful sanctuary of the museum and grounds.The grounds are lovely and the buildings are magnificent. There is also a selection of Balinese art from traditional to modern; from subdued colours to very vibrant (over the top colours).The only downside is that there are many similar artworks in each section--I would have liked more diversity within the styles. However, we did enjoy it a great deal and was surprised and delighted by the modern art.

Good cross section of Balinese art. Enjoyed the diversity of art on display. As mentioned by other reviewers the architecture in which the paintings are displayed and the garden surrounds are also worth the visit.
Beautiful!. Of the Ubud museums, this is the best, in my opinion. The buildings themselves are handsome, the gardens are beautiful, and the exhibits very well done.

Great first stop in Ubud. We happened to make ARMA our first major destination in Ubud, and it was a wonderful gateway to the culture and art in this amazing city. The grounds are stunning, the exhibits fascinating, and the little cafe is a great place to unwind and enjoy an iced coffee. We returned the following day to take a woodcarving class...just me, my husband and our teacher. It was a truly unique experience, and I loved learning even a little of this stunning art form.
ARMA. Beautiful gardens and buildings - our family with young kids spent a very relaxing few hours enjoying the artwork, the landscaping and the iced tea in the cafe,

Great contemporary collection.. The Agung Rai Museum wins out for its superb collection of contemporary Balinese (and SE Asian) art. Oh, and for the sheer fact of the presence, within its walls, of what is probably the sole, authentic Walter Spies painting on public view in Bali. While the ARMA is a bit wanting in the curatorial department – there are precious few explanatory wall texts or labels to be spotted, as well as an entire gallery of er, reproductions of Spies paintings – the strength of its displays, and the broad scope of its collection are pretty impressive. The usual suspects are also here, of course: there was a temporary exhibition of contemporary Batuan paintings while I was there (accompanied by a thick catalogue, terribly imposing), and you get plenty of mythological subjects on cloth, depictions of everyday scenes and lush forestscapes and stylized animals, and ghosties and ghoulies and black magic hokum, as well as works executed in that shining exemplar of Indonesian art, the Mooi Indie style. It’s when one gets to the annexe next to the main building, though, that things really take off: the Spies, a rendering of the Calonarang folktale, is here, as is a vaguely Matisse-esque painting of loincloth-clad Balinese men by Dutch artist Auke Sonnega, the whole affair just simmering with Bazille-ian homoeroticism. There are also more recent pieces: large-scale conceptual work by Walter van Oel, and stuff from Singaporean artists (look out for the still-life by Wee Shoo Leong - brilliant). Oh, and the price of admission includes a free cuppa joe. Real nice of these guys.

Serene grounds and inspiring art. We only had one day in busy Ubud, so did not get to compare this to other museum offerings. However, we found the sprawling grounds to be incredibly tranquil and well kept. The art itself was a lovely collection and we had the opportunity to meet Agung Rai who really inspired us to see the "art in nature". Bali is truly a beautiful place. We were lucky that they were featuring new art with the launch of a new book (Inventing Art: the Paintings of Batuan Bali) and so we were able to purchase an original piece.Free coffee or tea with admission ticket at the lovely cafe. We were tempted to eat lunch at the Thai restaurant onsite and I still dream about the wonderful villas that you can stay in. Heavenly retreat. A nice way to see Balinese art in its purest form amidst lovely surroundings. We spent way more time walking the grounds than we did looking at art, but the experience was wonderful.

Well worth the walk!. A bit of a walk (always a challenge in motorbike clogged Ubud) from the village center but not too far from the Monkey Forest is a real find: the Agung Rai Museum of Art. The grounds are quiet and serene, a wonderful respite from the sometimes crazy streets of Ubud. We are not art buffs, but still enjoyed the gallery and it had a good variety of works from earlier centuries to more recent additions. The coffee shop was a great place to spend an our (or two) and the admission ticket includes a free cup of (hot or iced) coffee or tea. We also went back in the evening for a dance performance. I'm not a connoisseur of Balinese dance, but the dancers seemed enthusiastic and the length of the performance was just right. Good English-language programs kept us informed about what we were watching. Ordinarily the dance is held on an outdoor stage which I'm sure adds something to its not already inconsiderable charms, but the threat of rain moved it indoors to the gallery lobby. Somehow being surrounded by modern Balinese art provided an even more interesting backdrop for the performance. Lots of good dance troupes and venues in Ubud, but I would recommend this one.
Excellent quality. Very good quality art. They even have a Donald Friend. Also, on the day, I saw craftsman creating carvings. Excellent quality!

Learn Gamelan & Balinese Dance. We went to ARMA looking for a unique experience and we found it!Tired of the usual tourist traps we wanted to learn a little bit more about Balinese dancing and the Gamelan. Inspired as well by the beautiful Balinese dances we saw and the entrancing Gamelan Orchestra music we asked around and were surprised to find that very few people knew about ARMA.A bit of a gamble but worth taking at such reasonable prices. The Gamelan and Dance workshops cost us $25 US each but lasted for 2 hours. We made sure we came at a quiet time, 1100 AM and had the instructors one-on-one which helps if your Bahasa Indonesia is a bit rusty. We were told that they do cater for larger groups as well.Knowing the Indonesian language would be an advantage but even if you didn't you would still find this a remarkable experience. This would be an ideal excursion for students of the Indonesian Language at any level.Definitely a wonderful experience and created a desire to learn more at a later time...worth a try!

Intricate Balinese art.. Not being a big arty or museum type person, I was determined to have a look at something while I was in Ubud. I really enjoyed coming here and looking at the Modern art and the more traditional and intricate Balinese art. Makes you appreciate what some folks do for a living. I found the Walter Spies exhibit interesting, because I had read a little about him beforehand.

Inspiring. Beautiful peaceful surroundings, and an art collection housed in two buildings. One is all art done by Balinese artists, the other is ROW, mainly Europe. I didn't like the ex-Bali paintings at all, not one of them! Soul-less stuff. (Hence 4 not 5 stars!) However, I could have spent many more hours with the Balinese work. Supremely beautiful, tender, exquisite soft colours, and a good range from quite old paintings to modern ones. Mind-boggling detail on large canvases, scenes from religious and personal life, depicted of deities and people and animals. Don't miss the large wooden Rama-Sita, carved from a hibiscus tree.... beyond beautiful, it is luminous, transpersonal and yet utterly human in its portrayal of intimacy. Also don't miss the Kecak trance-dance troupe who perform there on the lunations (New and Full Moons) ... reputed to be the best. I've seen them many times and never fail to be inspired.
ARMA Museum. Very nice grounds, but visited this after the Blanco Museum which was more interesting. Cost 60,000 rupiah which included a coffee in the cafe afterwards.

Great selection of paintings showing the evolution of art in Bali. This is worth a look...probably not the highest priority but it's a very nice place to stroll through historical buildings and examin the history of paintining (by natives and ex-pats) in Bali. The artwork is quite remarkable, most of it based on Hindu legends so there is some redundancy but the work is high quality and there is some diversity of content. The buildings themselves are interesting too.The 3-5 Balinese dance lessons are worth seeing but probably not hanging around for. In the end it's cute but after about 5 minutes you get a sense of what it is about.
a great place. is a great place , lot of arts exibition, incredible collection, place to discover with attention and interest, place where is situated to is very beautiful garden around.

Great overview of 20th century Balinese art. This museum features an eclectic collection of Balinese art, together with some European and Javanese art in a smaller side building. The main building's collection is great, featuring pre-war Balinese art (including I Gusti Nyoman Lempad and contemporaries), some double-ikat weaving displays, a feature on Walter Spies (albeit reproductions of works) and a very good collection of post-war Balinese art. The earlier art on the second level interested me more, though the more modern art was also worthwhile seeing. The second building, featuring mainly non-Balinese art that tended to be more aligned with Western art, was not as interesting and I skipped some of the works. There was also a temporary exhibition on the ground floor of the entrance building whose subject was owls, which held some interest for me.Conservation practices are better here than in the Puri Lukisan Museum in Ubud and works of art tend to be in a much better condition overall. I would rate this museum as slightly better as Lukisan, though the latter has some pre-20th century art.The entrance fee is Rp 40000 per person and includes a coffee from the cafe behind the main art building. The collection is quite extensive, so allow 1.5-2 hours to see most things.
Interesting.... The place is nice...inside a great garden...with two coffea where you can have a break after visiting the museum (the offer you a drink with the entrance ticket!)

An calm oasis of art and gardens. A combination of interesting buildings housing the collections, sculpture, well tended gardens and a small cafe make this well worth the trip. Away from the main street it may be overlooked but make a point of visiting if you are an art lover.

ARMA. This museum is the home for quite a lot of Balinese painting. If you can appreciate arts (unfortunately I'm not art lover), you'll certainly love this place. I actually interested in taking the course more than the museum. So, tips for those who interested to go, check the schedule for courses. They have courses for gamelan, batik, carving, cooking, etc. Check the website for details.
interesting art museum. Very interesting art work showing the development of the island culture. And adds an education of Hindu religion also

Peaceful and interesting. This gorgeous place is a bit far away from Jalan Raya, but the walk worth it. You are welcomed with good explanations and a ticket for a coffee or a tea in a pleasant warung after. The 2 buildings are very interesting, with great paintings, of Walter Spies for example. The garden is quiet, peaceful and you can stay inside for a long time without noticing time passing.ARMA has also a lot of various classes (music, balinese dance,...) but we didn't try them.It was a very good moment, out of the noisy road Hanoman St.

Beautiful museum and gardens. ARMA, along with the Neka and a couple of others, is one of the main art venues in Ubud, set in several acres of beautiful gardens above and along the river. In addition to the museum, and two open stages for dance performances, the compound includes a resort area with what looked to be rather swanky bungalows fronting the rice fields. The caretaker told us that the place had been neglected for some years and was only now seeing some money come in to refurbish some of the buildings. Few people seem to visit this place; other than us, I saw two others and they did not make the journey down to the rest of the compound. It’s too bad because the collection is interesting and the grounds are fantastic. See pictures here: http://lmaclean.ca/2011/10/ubud-rice-field-walk-and-more-art/

Beautiful location for an art museum. Whether you are curious about Balinese art or would just like to check out a beautiful garden, I would recommend a visit to ARMA. We enjoyed the buildings' architecture just as much as the variety of Balinese art, which was quite impressive. Afterward, we took some lovely pictures in their gardens and stopped for a drink in their outdoor cafe (which is included in the price of your ticket). It's a very peaceful location and when we went there weren't many people there at all. It's definitely worth checking out.

Uniquely Designed. This museum is designed to fit the works held within. Much of the art was taken from Bali but has been reclaimed and brought here. I enjoyed the lower level where barongs and other interesting pieces of the Bali culture can be enjoyed. Work continues, as in beautiful carvings currently being done by volunteers.

Very informative. We decided to spend the rainy morning at this museum. Since we can't go sightseeing in Ubud town because of the rain, this museum seemed to be a very good choice. And we were right. The museum compound itself is very huge. It has 2 big Balinese style houses and they have Balinese arts through the century, from paintings to sculptures by local artists. But best of all is the garden. Its huge and very traditional. Lots of specialists wood carvers working their skills all over the compound when we were there. I guess the Museum itself was having a refurbishment. They didn't bother me at all since they use traditional methods, carving away all those woods. All in all, I like this museum and found it very informative.

Great for a relaxing afternoon. Let me start by saying that I am not much into art. At all. But since the house I was staying at (visiting family) was literally next door to the ARMA I figured I had to go and I don't regret a single second of my visit. The paintings are far from what I was used to seeing. Took my time, soaked up the atmosphere. Your entrance ticket comes with a free coffee or tea.
