After taking my time at the 2 museums I sat and enjoyed my tea reading the newspaper. One of the employees told me I should go down to the ARMA resort because they have a beautiful watergarden there. So I did and he was right ... beautiful indeed. I also sat and watched the childeren's danceclass (3 pm). Before heading back home I informed about their workshops. Turns out the ARMA has plenty of them so if you want to really learn about Bali doing one of the workshops might be fun. I booked a danceclass which was a lot of fun (you just have to tell the teacher to slow down the pase sometimes). All in all I spent a little over 4 hrs. there the first time and the danceclass was 2 hrs. Well worth a visit.

terrific pendet and legong dance at night. the place is super huuuuuugeeeee. the dance performance is held at 7.30 pm every night and we managed to catch the pendet and legong dance. too bad we didn't have time to visit during the day.the cafe also serves nice, extravagant cuisine. i tried the traditional Balinese nasi campur; it is quite big and filling with sate, tuna sambal matah and ayam betutu. it's an outdoor cafe and we saw a mouse jog across the floor, but i guess they can't help it :D

A must-see, especially at night. There isn't a lot to do in Ubud unless you want to visit 20 different spas, and while this museum wouldn't win any prizes elsewhere, it's worth visiting. In the evening, they present Balinese dance, which was a highlight for us. Unless you don't like gamelan music, in which case give it a miss.
Excellent collection, great garden. The collection is great. And even if you're not into arts (paintings and sculptures), the landscape is so nice you can just bring a book and read there.

Lovely place, well worth a visit. We really enjoyed the ARMA museum and the first rate evening dance performance at this important Ubud cultural center. We also enjoyed meeting and talking to Agung Rai who was gardening when we arrived. The restaurant was lovely and peaceful with above average food and service. If you are in Ubud, this should be on your list. It is close to everything in Ubud but feels relaxed and away from it all.

Cultural Treasures. Great place to visit when you are in Ubud. Artists works are in display. Central place for arts and culture. Definitely stop by and try their lunch at the restaurant. Pleasant, peaceful. Fun to check out.

One of the best Museums in Ubud.. As with many of the museums and galleries in Ubud, the buildings and gardens are worth visiting almost as much as the exhibits. The paintings are nicely presented and we found there were enough to occupy us for an hour or two. The entry fee includes a complementary drink in the cafe which is in a nice setting in the Museum grounds with a small rice field on one side. Apparently, if you visit at the right time of the week, you can also see dance lessons etc. Toilets were clean and pleasant which is a bonus!

Worthy Visiting. We've discovered this museum our first night in Ubud due to the Barong dance performance, held in it's grounds. The performance was shortened due to the tropical rain and we went to ARMA Cafe adjacent to the museum to wait for the taxi. Next day we went to the museum proper and enjoyed it very much because it's situated in several nice pavilions in Balinese style, in lovely garden, and the good collection of both traditional and contemporary Indonesian paintings is well commented upon (in English as well). Considered one of the best in Indonesia. Admission is Rp 40.000,-.

Nice enough for an hour or so. This museum has some interesting modern pieces from known Balinese artists and western artists with a relationship with Bali. The location is lovely and you can have a stroll around the fabulous looking resort as well. The warung kopi that is part of the museum serves good coffee in a luxury and relaxed environment. The cake we tried was delicious.The entrance fee includes a complementary hot/iced (Bali) coffee or tea at warung kopi.

Lovley experience!. I spend one afternoon at this very nice museum in Ubud. Some of the paintings were impressive, especially one painting by Ida Bagus depicting a firedancer. But what really made this visit memorable was the balinese garden that surronded the art museum. The garden is full of sculptures but you can only see them if you look carefully. Apart from all the sculptures the garden has lovley lilyponds and a lot of orchids. This museum is well worth a visit even if you are not particulary fond of or interested in the art exhibitions presented. I am very interested in art but my travelcompanion is not but she loved the museum anyway.Don´t forget to bring your camera! If you - like me - love the lush green balinese gardens and landscape you will have a lot of opportunities to take nice photos.

An excellent art museum. Entrance is Rs 50,000 and includes a complimentary tea or coffee in the cafe. ARMA is open from 9am to 6pm daily. A great collection in lovely gallery spaces. Don't miss it. Make sure you visit Neka Art Museum (different to Neka Gallery) and Museum Puri Lukisan as well.

One of the top 3 Museums in Ubud. The Agung Rai Museum of Art (ARMA) is more than a museum, it also is a place for theater performances, dance, music, painting classes, workshops, seminars, etc.There are a series of buildings and some of them house permanent collections of paintings and also temporary exhibitions. There is usually something going on everyday. ARMA is also a Resort and they have taken over the Kokokan Hotel which is in the same area as the Museum. In addition there is the Kokokan Club, a Thai Restaurant in the same area. The cost to enter the Museum I think was around $3, more than reasonable, so see on the finest Museums in Ubud.
